title: troye sivan interview top bottom question boyfriend shawn mendes
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsSinger and actor was also asked whether his boyfriend would give him a 'hall pass' to sleep with Shawn MendesClick to followThe Independent CultureTroye Sivan has called out an interviewer who asked several inappropriate questions during a&nbspconversation with the South African-born Australian singer.In a rapid-fire Q&ampA that was published in the September issue of LGBT+ magazine Express, the gay musician was asked whether he was “top or bottom” by reporter Matt Fistonich.“Ooo… definitely passing!” the 24-year-old was quoted as responding.Created with Sketch.The 35 best debut albums of all time Show all 35Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.135 35) Arctic Monkeys – Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not (2006)A new wave of British guitar bands was already being pioneered by the likes of The Libertines, Bloc Party and Franz Ferdinand when the Sheffield-formed Arctic Monkeys arrived on the scene. But their 2006 debut – the defiantly titled Whatever People Say I Am, That’s What I’m Not – is arguably the most generation-defining, by a band experiencing the kind of hype that hadn’t been seen since Oasis with Definitely Maybe. Alex Turner’s sardonic and keenly observational lyrics on songs like “Fake Tales of San Francisco” and “When the Sun Goes Down” had fans clamouring to get into their early shows. It was an early example of the power the internet would hold over the music industry – propelling them from an unknown indie band on MySpace to the top of the charts in the space of six months.Please Please Me has a rhythm to it like little else released by The Beatles. Songs like “Twist and Shout” and “I Saw Her Standing There” have an energy that reflects the youthful vim of the band themselves, who were raring to go following the number one single from which the album takes its name. Their harmonies are thrilling to hear, and this is arguably the best album for capturing the band’s raw power.335 33) Yeah Yeah Yeahs – Fever to Tell (2003)In 2003, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs stuck a middle finger up to the naysayers who scoffed that they were little more than a bunch of posers. Their debut album Fever to Tell is a bristling record loaded with New York snark supplied by Karen O’s impressive vocal turns. Nick Zinner keeps the urgency going with roaring guitar licks while Brian Chase offers earth-shaking percussion on the likes of “Date With the Night” and “Y Control”. More than trendsetters – the Yeah Yeah Yeahs were the brains behind the smartest album of that year.Kanye West called it “white crunk music”. The band themselves called it “music for girls to dance to”. And songs such as “This Fire” certainly livened things up their irresistible hooks and disco energy, as frontman Alex Kapranos turned the male gaze on its head with lyrics like “I can feel your lips undress my eyes”. Fifteeen years later and “Take Me Out” still makes you swing your hips.Blur versus Oasis is a battle music fans will be waging for decades to come, but when it comes to debut albums, Oasis emerge as top dogs. Definitely Maybe was exciting, aggressive and loaded with attitude: a 22-year-old Liam Gallagher spits and snarls over the reverb-soaked guitars of “Cigarettes &amp Alcohol”, and soars on that falsetto for “Live Forever”. Among the “too cool for school” alt-rockers who spurned the glitz and glamour of fame, Oasis asserted themselves as the definitive rock and roll stars.Stefani Germanotta’s debut album The Fame brought maximalist pop back to the forefront of the late-Noughties music scene, in an industry that was desperately lacking in pop as. Lady Gaga already sounded famous and she acted famous – but that doesn’t mean her music couldn’t stand on its own. Songs like “Beautiful, Dirty, Rich” and “Just Dance” seemed to convey Gaga’s love of fame and hedonism while remaining supremely self-aware of its superficiality. To top it off, it was masterfully produced and resplendent with slick, catchy dancepop and Eurodisco influences.Kendrick Lamar subtitled his debut record “A Short Film by Kendrick Lamar”, and indeed it feels as though you’re watching the movie of his early life – such is the autobiographical nature of this record. He raps in low, furtive tones, interrupted by voicemails from his family (his mother asks him pleadingly to return her car) that reinforce the familial themes. It is family, and faith, that keep Lamar on the outskirts of a world of violence and sin. Even this early on his career you hear the virtuosity and acute understanding of rhythm – Good kid, m.A.A.d City now stands as a classic album from a rapper who chooses the power of storytelling over a cheap punchline.Not every great debut album is defined by whether the artist has landed on their “sound” by the first track. Led Zeppelin were still figuring things out when they released their self-titled debut, yet it is essential because it laid the groundwork for what they would go onto achieve the following decade. “We were learning what got us off most and what got people off most,” Robert Plant said. You had the blues and folk notes on “Babe I’m Gonna Leave You”, and the chugging rock of “Communication Breakdown” Plant’s yowling vocals and Jimmy Page’s guitar. It did the trick.935 27) The Jesus and Mary Chain – Psychocandy (1985)“It was the crap coming out of the radio that made us want to be in a band more than anything else,” Jim Reid told Rolling Stone for the 30th anniversary of the Scottish alt-rocker’s debut album Psychocandy. “Because it was like, ‘Why is everything we hear so f***ing awful?’ That was the main driving force: how bad things were.” Psychocandy was certainly like nothing anyone else released at that time. Inspired by the Velvet Underground and The Stooges, the Reid brothers loaded their debut with buzzy guitars and hair-raising levels of feedback on singles like “You Trip Me Up” and “Never Understand”. It paved the way for countless shoegaze and alt-rock bands in the decades that followed.Grace is a masterpiece, and the only album the perfectionist Jeff Buckley was satisfied with before he drowned, aged 30, in a freak accident in Memphis in 1997. Yet had Grace been the only material ever released under his name (live recordings, covers and demos were released posthumously), it would have been enough to prove he was a rare and exceptional talent. His exquisite rendering of Leonard Cohen’s “Hallelujah”, his melismatic singing on “Grace” and the church-like hush of “Lover, You Should Come Over” – all of this and more carved out a rich legacy that ensures Buckley’s music will never fade.The whipsmart, cynical, outrageous young man on Eminem’s major label debut was a breath of fresh air – or perhaps more of a slap in the face – after a spate of soulful, conscious hip hop records. Of course, the rampant misogyny and homophobia his so-called “character” Slim Shady spat out caused uproar, regardless of how surreal the scenarios to which they were applied were.  Arguably what stands out the most on The Slim Shady LP is the sheer technical skill and lyrical ability that few have been able to match since.Not only did it lay the groundwork for so many punk, rock and heavy metal bands that came after them – but the manic rhythms and raw intensity of their power-chord ballads featured on The Who's my Generation propelled rock and roll to new heights in 1965.“Saviours of rock and roll!” “The greatest rock band since the Rolling Stones!” You have to pity The Strokes, who released their debut album under the biggest wave of hype imaginable. Yet it’s hard to deny the impact Is This It had on rock music – critics have argued that the Arctic Monkeys and Franz Ferdinand wouldn’t have existed if not for this band. They eschewed pre-programmed beats and autotuned vocals in favour of a gritty post-punk approach, and the result was an album that reinvigorated a floundering music industry, and inspired an entire generation of bands.The idea of a rap album was virtually inconceivable until Run-DMC released their full-length, self-titled debut in 1984. When he inducted them into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, Eminem called them “the first movie stars of rap… they are The Beatles”. Busta Rhymes proclaimed: “Run-DMC didn’t change music, they changed everything.” The trio’s aggressive yet stark tracks – like “Sucker MCS” and “Hard Times” – were a dramatic contrast against the R&ampB-driven rap of the time, an approach emulated by the rappers themselves, who spurned outlandish costumes in favour of tracksuits and sneakers. As an anniversary piece in Billboard noted, “they were authentic before authenticity in hip hop was even a thing”.Brian Eno’s experimental synths met Bryan Ferry’s romantic, old-school charm on the debut album from Roxy Music's bizarre art-glam-rock outfit. There were odes to Humphrey Bogart (“2HB”) and cyber-rock jams (“Ladytron”), and songs decorated with spooky-sounding hooks that wouldn’t sound out of place in The Rocky Horror Show (the character Riff Raff even seemed to take his cues from a balding Brian Eno).Still regarded by many as his greatest album to date, Reasonable Doubt asserted Jay-Z as a master freestyle – perhaps the best of his generation – recorded in a studio he compared to a psychiatrist’s couch. At the heart of the record is a blistering duet with the Notorious BIG, “Brooklyn’s Finest”, which practically heralded the shift of focus back from West Coast hip hop to the East.Rolling Stone's Lester Bangs described the Black Sabbath as “just like Cream! But worse”, and their debut album as “a shuck – despite the murky song titles and some inane lyrics that sound like Vanilla Fudge paying doggerel tribute to Aleister Crowley, the album has nothing to do with spiritualism, the occult, or anything much except stiff recitations of Cream clichés”. The Village Voice weren’t keen either, with critic Robert Christgau condemning it as “bulls**t necromancy.” Yet this is the album that invented heavy metal. Black Sabbath arrived ready to lure fans over to the dark side with Ozzy Osbourne’s piercing, operatic cry: “My name is Lucifer, please take my hand.” Critics be damned.1835 18) Sex Pistols – Never Mind the Bollocks, Here's the Sex Pistols (1977)“The album will last. The sleeve may not,” said the adverts for the Sex Pistols’ first and only studio album in 1977. The Sex Pistols were already controversial before the release of Never Mind the Bollocks, having caused nationwide uproar for swearing on live TV, been fired from two record labels, and been banned from a number of live venues in England. Yet despite many major retailers refusing to sell it, the album debuted at number one on the UK album charts and is today regarded as one of the most important punk albums in music history.Joe Strummer was a ball of rage and ambition when he and the rest of The Clash laid down the tracks for their debut album. Most of the guitar on this record was provided by Mick Jones, because Strummer didn’t think technical ability was punk enough. Yet their vision burns through on the buzz-saw attack of “Career Opportunities” and “White Riot”, raising a fist against unemployment, racism and the fat cats of industry. 2035 16) Guns N Roses – Appetite for Destruction (1987)Guns N Roses' Appetite for Destruction was the biggest thing to happen to hard rock since Led Zeppelin IV. Slash’s guitar and Axl Rose’s wild, animal howls contribute to the raw energy on songs like “Paradise City” and marked a dramatic shift away from the commercialised heavy rock that was being played on MTV at the time – proudly championing a gritty form of hedonism instead. “A lot of rock bands are too f***ing wimpy to have any sentiment or emotion,” Rose said. Not this band.Daft Punk's Homework was originally intended as “just a load of singles”, until Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo realised they had enough quality tracks for a full-length release. Each one opens with a kind of motif upon which multiple textures build and sprawl outwards – sleazy guitar hooks, G-funk whines and glittering synths. It’s the album that alerted the rest of the world to the French house music scene.Sex and poetry go hand in hand, especially if you’re a Jim Morrison fan. failing to “recognise the complexity of life”.The proposals&nbspare&nbspthe first test on&nbsphousing policy for Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government, which has said it aims to tackle&nbspthe housing crisis and increase&nbsphome ownership.To achieve this goal, ministers also unveiled new plans for the shared ownership scheme, which allows&nbspfirst-time buyers earning less than £80,000 a year (£90,000 in London) to incrementally buy shares in&nbspa home and pay subsidised rent to a housing association, starting with the purchase of an initial share worth at least 25 per cent.But Halep ended the teenagers dream run at the tournament in their round 16 match, 6-3, 6-3.Experts said the&nbspproposal to incentivise people to remain in their community&nbsp“doesn’t recognise the complexity of life” and would only help a small percentage for whom home ownership is just out of reach – but not the millions for whom it is a distant goal.Shelter chief executive Polly Neate said: “We don’t think this plan will help people in the greatest housing need.&nbspThere are 800,000 private renters in this country who can’t even afford to save £10 a month. What those people need is genuinely affordable social homes.”While the 20 per cent reduction was not included in the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government’s (MHCLG) statement, a spokesperson confirmed ministers were considering the proposals and said it would offer further details “in due course”.The proposals that were officially announced by the government on Wednesday morning were met with mixed reactions.More than 210,000 children homeless in England, finds reportCurrently, those using the shared ownership scheme can only purchase their home in increments of 10 per cent, which can be prohibitively expensive, costing up to £45,000 each.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailUnder new plans, pending consultation, people would be allowed to buy shares of&nbsptheir house one per cent at a time.But critics warned administrative costs involved in purchasing further shares&nbsp– such as legal, mortgage arrangement and&nbspvaluation fees&nbsp–&nbspcould render&nbspthe proposal&nbsp”unworkable”.The&nbspMHCLG&nbspsaid it wants to make buying smaller chunks a simple, quick process that bypasses the current costly and sometimes lengthy valuations system and will explore the best way to achieve this.Pedzai fears deportation back to Zimbabwe after almost five year waitMr Jenrick's department&nbspalso announced it had closed a loophole allowing those using the Help to Buy scheme to take on a 35-year mortgage, which until ths week had been capped at 25 years.This would make mortgage payments more affordable but leave people with greater interest to pay off in the long run.Ms&nbspNeate&nbspinstead urged the government to “get building”.“Pinning his hopes on yet another complicated housing scheme is a worrying start for the new housing secretary,” she said.&nbsp“The government must realise that unworkable schemes, laden down with admin costs, are the wrong priority at any time – and are woefully inadequate when this country is facing the current housing emergency.Homeless people denied access to basic healthcare, finds study“If the new government is serious about getting to grips with our housing crisis then it must follow through on its commitment to get building. That’s why we’re calling for 3 million more social homes over the next 20 years, to give more families the sort of step-up they actually need in life.”The MHCLG also plans to increase&nbspthe number of homes sold at discounted prices to people trying to get onto the property ladder&nbspand help&nbspbuild local support for new developments, Wednesday’s statement said.But homeless&nbspcharity&nbspCentrepoint&nbspsaid the proposed changes would “have little impact on the most vulnerable people in need of housing”.The number of people sleeping rough in England has&nbspskyrocketed by 165 per cent in the last eight years, with a homeless person dying every 19 hours&nbspin the UK, data from the Museum of Homelessness suggests.Centrepoint’s head of&nbspmedia and&nbsppublic&nbspaffairs Paul Noblet said in light of increases in debt and the cost of rent, he welcomed any move by government to make home ownership more affordable.“However, for the homeless young people Centrepoint supports, home ownership is not always a realistic or practical option – so the proposed changes will have little impact on the most vulnerable people in need of housing,” he said.“To ensure that everyone can have a place to call home the government must ensure it focuses financial resources as much on increasing the supply of social housing as it does on home ownership.”Mr Jenrick, 37, described his first major policy announcement as “radical”, saying: “Building the houses this country needs is a central priority of this government.“We know that most people still want to own their own home, but for many the dream seems a remote one.&nbspMy mission is to increase the number of homes that are being delivered and to get more young people and families onto the housing ladder, particularly those on lower incomes.“That’s why I am announcing radical changes to shared ownership so we can make it simpler and easier for tens of thousands trying to buy own their own home.”Homeless man dies and second fighting for life after ‘arson attack’Building more homes won’t solve UK housing crisis, new report arguesWhy has Brexit sparked a mini boom in the housing market? But Ms Neate suggested the government could learn from other countries to address the crisis.She referred to schemes in Norway, in which people pay into a housing cooperative rather than making payments on their inidual home to a housing association. This scheme negates some of the costs associated with purchasing new shares.The MHCLG proposals underline Mr&nbspJohnson’s&nbspdesire to shift from Theresa May’s focus on improving renters rights, to increase home ownership and give young people “a&nbspstake in society, the ability to own at least a share of their home”.While Mr&nbspJohnson has stated an intention to build 300,000 new homes a year and make use of brownfield sites – former industrial or commercial lots – none of Wednesday’s&nbsppolicy proposals referred to the building of new&nbsphouses.A spokesperson for Labour’s shadow minister for housing said if homes aren’t being built, it doesn’t matter how large&nbspa proposed discount is.Shadow housing minister Sarah Jones said: “Tinkering with the details of shared ownership is meaningless when lack of investment from government means low cost homes for ownership simply aren’t getting built.&nbspThe Tories have failed to deliver the low-cost homes we need to get people on the housing ladder.”Just one&nbspper cent&nbspof all homeowners have accessed shared ownership, while the number&nbspof these and other low-cost homes being built each year has almost halved since its peak in 20078, when 200,000 new homes were built.However, director of policy and research at the National Housing Federation, Catherine Ryder, said: “We very much welcome the news that the government is looking at ways to make staircasing in shared ownership easier.&nbsp“Shared ownership is the best route into home ownership for people who can’t afford to buy outright and housing associations, who built 14,000 shared ownership homes last year, are committed to working with the government to continue improving it.”The MHCLG has been contacted for comment.Share your thoughts and debate the big Feeding hormones to cattle is widespread practise among American beef farmers.But Sir Ian said he was satisfied hormone-treated beef was also safe.Is chlorinated chicken bad for our health and the environment?“The chances are that most of it will have been metabolised when it comes into the meat you would eat,” said the Defra adviser. “The chances of it having any biological effect on us is almost infinitesimally small.”The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) opposes chlorine-washed poultry because it enables farmers to lower their welfare standards, since they can use a&nbspchemical bath to kill off any harmful pathogens after animals are slaughtered.Earlier this month Zippy Duvall, the head of the American Farm Bureau, said fears over the practices are not “science-based”.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: uk supermarkets offers discounts which consumers chain
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsMisleading pricing uncovered at Asda, Iceland,&nbspMorrisons,&nbspOcado, Tesco and Waitrose, with only&nbspSainsbury’s&nbspfully compliant with rulesClick to followThe IndependentAsda, Iceland and Morrisons are among major UK supermarkets pushing “dodgy deals” that do the opposite of saving their customers money, according to an investigation by Which?.Over the course of a year, the consumer organisation looked at more than 450 products on offer online at the three supermarkets, as well as at Ocado, Sainsbury’s, Tesco and Waitrose. It found multiple “suspicious offers” in all of them apart from Sainsbury’s.Among the “misleading” discounts it discovered was an offer at Iceland to buy two packs of Kellogg’s Crunchy Nut for £4, which works out as £2 each. However, the pack price was just £1.49 a week earlier.Morrisons promoted Cathedral City Mature Cheddar Cheese as “was £3.50 now £2” for a week in September, even though the product was available for £2 the month before.Meanwhile, Asda labelled Wall’s Carte D’Or Strawberry Ice Cream “was £3.50 now £2”. But the 1l tub was sold at £2 for longer, with the so-called special offer running only for 12 weeks.Created with Sketch. Show all 9Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.According to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesAccording to the Which? High Street survey 201929 8. House of FraserHomebase has recently dropped the Bunnings association from its storesFollowing a Which? complaint in 2015, the government published new guidance to make sure retailers’ pricing practices comply with consumer law. The rules state that information presented to consumers must be fair, must not waste time or cause disappointment, and should not lead buyers to overspend.“Four years on from our super-complaint on misleading pricing practices, many of the big supermarkets are clearly still in the wrong, with numerous examples of dodgy discounts and never-ending offers,” said Natalie Hitchins, head of home products and services at Which?.“These retailers must stop tricking shoppers with deceptive deals and spurious special offers.”Which? will report its findings to the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), and Ms Hitchins urged the CMA to intervene if necessary.Only two of the supermarkets responded to Which? when presented with the findings. Iceland said it will review its promotional calendar, while Asda disagreed with the suggestion that its offers are misleading.“While most of the deals we monitored did represent good value, we spotted 65 instances across the year of supermarkets using misleading discounts that didn’t represent the bargains they claimed.”Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: labour shadow brexit secretary keir starmer pockets 125000 from law firm derailing britains eu exit
story: Former Director of Public Prosecutions Starmer - who was also involved with a failed witchhunt of Sun journalists – has revealed he was paid up to £ an hour by Mishcon de Reya.Mishcon was one of three law firms that brought the legal challenge to Theresa May’s Brexit plans in the High Court this week.Starmer, , was elected as a Labour MP for Holborn and St Pancras in May last year – a role which pays £,.Between June and the end of September this year he was paid £, by Mishcon de Reya for  hours of “legal advice” - a rate of £ per hour.Late last year he earned £, offering legal advice to the law firm for  hours – or £ an hour.He also revealed a payment of £, on May , , for work carried out before he became an MP.He lives in a £million house in North London with solicitor we Victoria, , and their two young children. He also co-owns a house in Surrey.RELATED STORIES" data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   nintchdbpict-e.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" SHIFTING BLAME Labours bigwig who started witch hunt against Sun journalists refuses to apologise despite acquittals " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   nintchdbpict.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Theresa May must not be blown off course by EU cheerleaders including Nick Clegg and Keir Starmer " data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   nintchdbpict.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Bonkers to pay to secure foreign NHS staff like Sube and prop up broken system " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   graphic-kav.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" TREVOR KAVANAGH Britains soaring new growth figures after Brexit give Blair a royal beating with Nissan putting the boot in " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   nintchdbpict-e.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Operation Elveden must go down as one of the most shameful and ­haphazard episodes in British legal ­history Mishcon de Reya first hired him in  as a part-time consultant for its business crime unit.He quit client work for the firm in April , but was reappointed as a consultant to its in-house academy in June this year.The MP stood down from that role after being appointed to the shadow cabinet last month.Starmer is the third key figure from the lacklustre £.m Operation Elveden witchhunt of Sun reporters to be employed by Mishcon de Reya.His former principal legal adviser at the Crown Prosecution Service Alison Levitt and former politan police assistant commissioner Sue Akers – who headed the bungled investigation – have also done work for the firm.This week Starmer refused to apologise after reporter Anthony France had his conviction overturned - meaning not one of  Sun journalists arrested were convicted.A spokeswoman for the law firm said: “Keir Starmer was a consultant to the Mishcon Academy, our in-house centre for learning and development.“The role did not involve client advice on any issue. Keir resigned as a consultant to the academy when he was appointed to the Shadow Cabinet.”A spokesman for Starmer’s office said: “MPs are required to register and declare fees received since the May  election even where those fees were earned before the election.“The register makes it very clear that in the case of Keir Starmer, the vast majority of his declared earnings represent payment for work undertaken by him as a lawyer before he became MP.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk general election what bookies oods latest
story: The inscrutable Tory bigwig could be wanting to bring a vote to the people shortly after a No Deal Brexit. Heres the latest.Boris Johnson, elected in July  by Conservative party members as Britains new Tory leader and PM, could trigger a general election.As of August , Coral is offering   odds on one taking place this year.Both PaddyPower and Betfair are offering  .William Hill is offering   odds, while Bet gives   chances.The entire race for Conservative Party leadership was centred around Brexit - Boris has said that he will try to secure a better Brexit deal, but promises thatthis isnt possible he will crash out without one.His support for a no-deal Brexit has sent at least five MPs running.Boris may want to trigger a general election before Brexits  day time limit is up in order to secure a bigger parliamentary majority to get his deal through Parliament.Johnsons staunch leave stance - as opposed to Theresa Mays dithering over Brexit - could see him win votes from members of other parties gunning to leave.Johnson’s chief strategist Dominic Cummings has suggested the Prime Minister could call a general election after October , evenhe lost a no-confidence motion, allowing for a no-deal Brexit whilst Parliament is dissolved.Despite it widely being parroted that a general election this year is inevitable, Boris has said he is against the idea of a snap election.Mr Johnson has ruled out having a general election before the UK leaves the EU which is currently set for October , .However, Bojo’s top aides are now saying they believe they could trigger a poll in September — evenRemainer MPs attempt to ­topple the Government.Labour’s health spokesman Jonathan Ashworth said that the NHS funding announcement raised speculation that an election could come “very soon”.With rumours of a General Election, bookies are offering odds on when the next one will take place.Below are the latest election odds given by bookmaker Coral as of August , :Elections in this country take place on a Thursday.By law, Parliament is dissolved  working days before a General election.

title: brexit key dates 2019 timeline
story: The UK is set to leave the EU on October . Here are some of key dates in the Brexit process.On November , , EU leaders agreed the UKs Brexit deal at the Brussels summit.The agreement on the UKs withdrawal was considered to be the best and only deal possible.On December , , Theresa May scrapped the vote on her Brexit in the Commons as it was due to fall to a heavy defeat.And on January  the Brexit vote failed by  votes to .Unable to push her deal through, May finally stepped down on June .Her successor, Boris Johnson, assumed office on July .In his first speech as PM, he hit out at Brexit doubters, doomsters and gloomsters who believe Brexit is destined for failure.Referring to the October  deadline, he said: We will do a new deal, a better deal that will maximise the opportunities of Brexit while allowing us to develop a new and exciting partnership with the rest of Europe.I have every confidence that in  days time we will have cracked it.JulyEarly JuneOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc beebflix licence fee toby young
story: But I’m afraid it isn’t enough — not nearly enough.If the BBC is to continue to be funded by the taxpayer, it must slash costs and scrap the licence fee altogether.This year has been an annus horribilis for the Beeb.Its dficulties began in February with the launch of BBC Scotland, a new channel north of the border with an annual budget of £million.Unfortunately, very few people have been tuning in.BBC Scotland’s flagship current affairs programme, The Nine, is watched by just , people — even fewer than Alex Salmond’s weekly chat show on Russia Today.But it’s more than tune in to The Seven, BBC Scotland’s nightly news show.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   JBM_COMP-rod-liddle.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentROD LIDDLE Parliament works AGAINST the people so BoJo is right to threaten to suspend it " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Boris Johnson is not a dictator, he is defending democracy from Remoaners " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentDANIEL HANNAN Its not Boris putting the Government at risk - its those deranged Remainers " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Remainers have no right to complain now that the tables have turned " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   MB-COMP-JANEMOORE.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentJANE MOORE Coleen will forgive silly fool Wayne again after club girl lt photograph " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-e.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" THE SUN SAYS Signing away powers to get Brexit over the line could cost Boris his job The Seven is one of  programmes on the new channel that at certain points between February  and June  had zero viewers, according to the British Audience Research Board.That’s quite an achievement, given that Scotland has a population of five-and-a-half million and the average viewer north of the border spends three hours and  minutes a day watching television.Then, in June, the BBC announced it would be breaking its promise to provide free TV licences to the over-s.The Director-General, Tony Hall, agreed to take on that responsibility from the Government as a condition of the BBC’s Royal Charter being renewed in .According to the terms of the deal, the Corporation would be able to put up the licence fee each year and, in , it would fund free TV licences for pensioners from June , .The Beeb’s Royal Charter was duly renewed and the licence fee went up in , in  and again in .Yet apparently it can no longer afford to keep its pledge. From next June, only those over-s on pension credit will be eligible for free TV licences — just one in five people.That means .million pensioners, including more than , service veterans, will have to find £. a yearthey want to continue watching television.To add insult to injury, the BBC then disclosed how much money it is paying its stars.Anti-Brexit activist and Match Of The Day presenter Gary Lineker is on £,,, Graham Norton is on £, and Claudia Winkleman is on £,.Lineker’s salary alone would pay for more than , TV licences.Asthat wasn’t bad enough, earlier this month the Beeb said it intends to spend £million on an advertising campaign to attract young viewers and listeners.That’s more than the annual budget of Radio .It’s particularly high, given that the BBC can advertise on its own TV channels and radio stations for free. Apparently, the money is going to be spent on targeting young people on social media.Are we really supposed to believe that the BBC cannot afford to pay for pensioners’ TV licences, but can fritter away £million on Facebook adverts There’s almost nothing Auntie won’t stoop to in its desperate pursuit of the “yoof” audience.It has earmarked £million to promote its new Sounds app — including spending £, to transform the London Eye into the “London Ear” — and poured money into a series of increasingly tawdry podcasts, such as Gemma Collins talking about her le, a reality-show round-up called Reality Tea, and Unexpected Fluids, in which teenagers tell embarrassing ­stories about when sex goes wrong.It’s all a far cry from Lord Reith’s mission to explain.No doubt the BBC is concerned about how few young people it manages to attract — and this manests itself in other ways, too, such as its massive investment in apps and podcasts and its extensive online coverage of ITV’s Love Island.Last year, Ofcom revealed that  to -year-olds are spending an average of an hour and  minutes per day consuming BBC content, which is about half the amount for all age groups.Even more worrying for the Corporation, one in eight young Brits consumes no BBC content at all. Why should they fork out £. for the licence fee, particularly as many of them will already be paying for subscription TV services The fundamental problem the Beeb faces is that consumers are becomingly increasingly accustomed to paying for the TV content they want to watch and resent having to pay a mandatory flat tax to a single provider.The equivalent would beeveryone who owns a phone, tablet or laptop had to pay £. for an “internet licence” to fund Apple’s iTunes, regardless of whether or not they use the service.It’s time to do away with the licence fee — for everyone, not just the over-s.That would mean stripping down the state-funded parts of the BBC to its core news and current affairs output and funding that out of general taxation.It should sell off its profitable private isions — such as BBC Studios, which has annual revenues of more than £billion — and plough the money into creating its own subscription service.With its global brand recognition and unrivalled back catalogue, not to mention its reputation for high-quality drama, the BBC could easily compete with commercial providers such as Netflix and Amazon Prime.Promising to scrap the licence fee would surely be a vote-winner for Boris Johnson.What other election pledge would save nearly every British household £. a year No s, no buts. When it comes to renewing the BBC’s Royal Charter, it’s time to say: “No deal.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Nobody is accusing him of any wrongdoing. But his statement over the weekend still left plenty of questions to answer, not least why he continued to pal up with Epstein even after the tycoon was locked up for a year for soliciting an underage prostitute.The Royal Family has been a rock of stability in British le for centuries, and while its members are — obviously — unelected, they are held to a higher standard. Prince Andrew’s explanation, such as it was, didn’t meet that bar.And in it, he also blamed the media an increasingly easy way for public ­figures to attempt to dodge legitimate questions.The truth isit wasn’t for the media, we wouldn’t know anything at all about the Prince’s relationship with Epstein a matter of profound public interest.If reports are correct that the Duke of York will help police with their inquiries, then good on him. title: boris has been a revelation since he took over brexit but signing away powers to get it over the line could cost him his job
story: Delivering on the referendum ought to make Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party redundant and ensure a Tory election win. But binning the toxic Irish backstop might not be enough eventhe EU agrees.There is plenty in Theresa May’s deal to bind our hands even after we have left.The Sun would still prefer a deal. But Farage will capitalise, understandably so,Boris signs away any sovereign powers in haste to get Brexit over the line. That could yet cost him power.This may all be moot. We do not see Brussels nor the Irish PM scrapping the backstop they have treated as holy writ.But when his own allies like Iain Duncan Smith warn him not to be satisfied solely with that, Boris must listen.WHO’S up for more years of bitter Brexit ision and political paralysis Not Leavers, who were sick of it long ago and are furious their vote hasn’t been fulfilled. Not the EU, either. Its leaders, Boris says, just want it done now too.But others ARE bent on prolonging the agony indefinitely. What are Labour, the Lib-Dems, the SNP, the Greens and the Exact Change brigade all smoking After all that’s happened, how can they still believe our best bet is to nully the referendum and hold a second, skewed to ensure a Remain verdict  Nothing is more certain to wreck Britain.Yet befuddled Corbyn, led by his scheming sidekick Keir Starmer, has signed Labour up to this lunacy and abandoned his Leave voters entirely.Riding high two years ago, Corbyn is now reduced to feebly branding No Deal a “bankers’ Brexit” or a “Trump-deal Brexit”, apparently unaware bankers funded Remain and that no Trump deal would ever involve the NHS.It is dog-whistle drivel for deranged anti-American Trots and the #FBPE losers whining about Brexit on Twitter.These diehard Remainers, trapped in their bubble, are a truly pitul bunch.THE shake-up of shared ownership rules for hard-up home buyers is a smart idea as far as it goes.But they still have to find or borrow  per cent upfront. Why not slash that to ten, or even one  And it still smacks of tinkering when the solution to turning millennials into home owners is both more obvious and far more radical:A bonfire of archaic planning rules and a massive increase in the total of affordable homes built each year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remainers porkie pies trade deals
story: By drawing his excited opponents into making accusations about yet more of Boris’s “porky pies”, he has skilfully drawn attention to the point he really wanted to make — that there are huge global opportunities for British food exportersonly we are prepared to make concessions in opening up our own food markets to the world.In fact,we start exporting pork pies to the Far East we will only be ing to what we were doing more than  years ago.In , Melton Mowbray bakers Evans  Hill reported they had received a large order of pork pies from Borneo — which is even further from Britain than Thailand.If we could do it then, without modern refrigeration, we can surely do it now. As Boris was arguing, the real barriers to trade are not practical ones — they are taxes and regulations.Remainers continually lecture us on the benefits of free trade with the EU — and they are right to do so. Hardly anyone really wants to leave without a deal. If we do have to take that route it will surely not be long before discussions on a free trade deal recommence.Yet those same Remainers bizarrely retreat in horror when anyone suggests we do a free trade deal with the US. “But we’ll have to eat chlorinated chicken,” they complain, as well as GM “Frankenstein” food.As shown by their failure yesterday to agree on a common course of action to thwart Brexit, Remainers are bumbling along in a state of confusion.But nothing demonstrates this better than their contradictory approach to free trade. They seem to think it a great benefit to the country when conducted with the EU, but a route to national disastercarried out with any other country.The charge that anyone will be forced to eat chlorinated chicken or GM foods is, needless to say, a far bigger porky pie than anything Boris has said on the subject.It is far from certain that a Johnson Government, when engaged in trade talks with the US, will make the concessions allowing these products into UK markets, butit does, then UK shoppers will continue to have a choice.They will still be able to buy chicken produced in Britain or the EU, or they will be able to choose to eat American chicken.I certainly have no fear of eating chicken which has been washed in chlorine. The idea that it is “dangerous” has been thoroughly debunked. Each of us ingests far more chlorine through drinking water than we ever would do through eating US-produced chicken.As for GM foods, we already eat them, vegans especially. The EU allows imports of GM soyafor simple practical reasons. Most of it is grown in the Americas and too many growers there use GM seed for non-GM soya to be sold as a separate product.If we want free trade we are not going to achieve it just by persuading other countries to open their markets to us. No, we will have to make the concession of opening our markets to them too. But there is no reason to be frightened.True, there are some products which need to be banned from sale for genuine health and safety reasons. But most of the EU’s food product standards are really just a form of protectionism in disguise, dreamed up to block competition for European farmers.If we do post-Brexit trade deals with the US and other countries — and in the process do away with the EU’s protectionist tarfs and product standards — some UK producers would suffer.But others would prosper as they enjoyed access to new export markets. Overall, as is almost always the case when trade barriers are taken down, we would benefit. Strong industries would grow and consumers would enjoy greater choice and lower prices.Boris’s vision of a global British pork pie industry shows the dference between him and the political opponents who spent much of yesterday scheming over how to stop him taking Britain out of the EU.While his glass is half full, theirs is half empty.They are driven by a pathological fear of le outside the EU.It is not that they have any great enthusiasm for the EU. After all, I haven’t heard one of them make a convincing case why the EU is an institution to be admired. It is just that they have a lack of ambition for Britain and so cling to EU membership.After meeting for several hours yesterday, what did the likes of Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer and Jo Swinson come up with That they want to extend Article  yet further, to prolong yet again the endless drt which unsettled markets and put off investment.Thanks to the Remain lobby’s endless infighting and self-indulgent argument over who it would like as a caretaker Prime Minister, that is exactly what is overwhelmingly likely to happen on October . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: banged up france
story: Instead, their spur-of-the-moment trip across the channel ended in disaster when immigration officials found a family of three hiding in their car boot - and decided that care worker Kaylee was trying to smuggle people into the UK.When they found the people in the car, I didnt panic, Kaylee says. I thought the police would know that [theyd broken into my car] and we’d be on way home.But instead, she was locked up in a rat-infested prison and forced to live next to a cruel mother who had doused her baby in bleach.Every year  Brits are arrested abroad and find themselves in terrying situations, holed up in cells, without lawyers, at the whim of a foreign police force and scared for their lives.In tonights episode of Channel  series Young, Dumb and Locked up in the Sun, Kaylee and two other young Brits tell their stories. Kaylee Carson’s decision to go on a short break to France was completely spontaneous and great fun – at the start. “My cousin said she needed tobacco and I said, ‘Let’s go to France and get you some – it’s cheaper,’” recalls Kaylee, who lives in Peterborough. “It was a four-hour drive to Dover. We got on the ferry straight away.It was boiling hot weather and we were standing at the front, breeze blowing in our hair, re-enacting Titanic! It was really nice.”After a lovely day spent sightseeing in Calais and buying cigarettes, they missed their ferry back but bought aticket from Dunkirk for am the following morning, booking a night in a hotel.When they went through security at the docks the next morning, a guard asked Kaylee to open her boot. She thought nothing of it - but under when she lted the lid she was horried.“My face dropped,” says Kaylee. “There was a family of three in there with a blanket wrapped around them and bags and bags of clothes. I guess they were trying to escape. I said, Get them out of my car, why are you in my car ”Kaylee was in shock and presumed they’d jumped into the boot when they were sleeping at the hotel.“I tried not to panic. I thought the police would know that and that soon we’d be on our way home,” says Kaylee.But it wasnt that easy.The pair were handcuffed and taken to a cell at the ferry port for questioning. “They said you’re lying to us,” says Kaylee. “They thought we’d set it up or real smugglers had asked us to do this. They were telling us we’re going to jail.”The penalty for human trafficking in France is up to  years in prison and a fine of up to £.million.“We begged them and pleaded and cried,” says Kaylee. “We told them we’ve got babies at home and jobs to go to.”But it made no dference. After a week spent in custody, Kaylee and her cousin were summonsed to court. They were told they were going to be kept on remand in prison while the investigation continued and the pair were transferred to a French jail in Lille. “It was quite scary, there was a lot of shouting,” says Kaylee. “The screw wasn’t soft, she was quite pushy and pushed you here, pushed you there. I wanted to turn around and smack her - it was surreal. They told us we were the only English girls in jail and we could stay together. It was really dirty. There were rats running around everywhere.”For  hours a day the pair were kept locked up in the cell, only allowed a half an hour break in the exercise yard in the morning and afternoon.Their fellow inmates were a nightmare. “We didn’t feel safe at all,” says Kaylee. “One of our glasses smashed and we kept a bit in our bra as it felt a bit safer.In one room one woman was screaming and shouting because she was in a bad mood and it went on all day, all night - it was awful.Then they put a girl next to us who had a baby with a black guy and she’d thrown bleach on the baby to try and turn the baby white. I was just disgusted that they put her near us and we banged on her wall all night and they moved her away.“I lost three stone, most of my baby weight,” says Kaylee. “But my cousin drove me crazy – anyone wouldyou were with them  hours a day.”Kaylee and her cousin were were convinced the “screws” were anti-British and messed with their heads, often banging on their doors in the middle of the night just to wake them up and once even turning off the water for  hours in their cell.Every day they woke up in hope and finally, after three months, they were asked to sign some paperwork and told to pack their stuff. They were released without charge and deported from France. “There was such excitement to see my daughter and to see my family and friends,” says Kaylee. “It was surreal, going onto the plane. I said, “give me a beer!” It felt like forever but it could have been so much worse. No more tobacco runs.”Huddersfield painter and decorator Robert Kaskovich had been on holiday to Thailand over a dozen times and loved it.“Going so many times over the years, I’d heard the stories of people being locked up but I’d never had one bit of trouble before this trip,” says Robert.Robert met James, his old mate from home, and the pair went south to the idyllic holiday island of Phuket with one plan: to drink and meet girls.“I’d come out of a relationship, he was single. It was just two lads going out, trying to pull women, having a laugh with them and meeting lots of people,” says Robert.They went to the infamous Bangla Road area of Phuket where the roads were lined with strip clubs, go go bars and nightclubs. Robert met an English girl who was living out there and he took her to get some food. title: families save jellyfish british beach 25c heatwave
story: Families pushed the enormous sea creature back to the waters on Bovisand beach in Devon on Tuesday afternoon as temperatures soared.But after all the effort to put the jellyfish back into the sea it apparently washed up dead an hour later.James Weir, , from Plymouth said: I was sat on the beach with my family and saw loads of people gathered around and I saw that there had been lots of barrel jellyfish recently, so I thought it was probably one of those.I walked up with my camera and it was massive.It was really cool to see it, especially the tentacles.People tried to lt it but it was really heavy, it was pretty massive.There were lots of people touching it and then some dragged it out to sea.I think it was dead. After they took it out an hour later it was back on the shore again. They are often seen in late spring and wash up on our beaches in May or June – sometimes in their hundreds. They are the size of dustbin lids - giving them their other common name: Dustbin-lid Jellyfish. The jellyfish have eight arms, which are frilly in appearance. These frills actually contain their small stinging tentacles which surround hundreds of mouths. A barrel sting is too weak to cause any serious harm to humans.Source: Wildle TrustsThere has been a huge increase in sightings of the animals as our seas warm up.Barrel jellyfish have washed up on the beaches all over Devon as the record-breaking hot weather attracts the creatures to the shores.James, a keen sailor, said he has spotted barrel jellyfish on every outing this season but never notice any in previous years.He said: I do a bit of sailing and every time I have sailed this season I think I have seen one in the water in Plymouth Sound by Drakes Island and other places.In June a jellyfish the size of a dustbin lid washed up on a Cornish beach.

story: NewsCouple who spent four years trying for a baby devastated after son dies at  days oldWARNING - UPSETTING IMAGES: Ria Constable and partner Aaron Marks were told their newborn son had two extremely rare heart defects which meant were unable to hold him before he was rushed emergency treatmentShareCommentsByKieran Murray:,  AUG NewsParents Ria Constable and Aaron Marks with their baby boy Leo at the Freeman Hospital "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Ria Constable and partner Aaron Marks were over the moon when they finally discovered that they were expecting a new arrival. The young couple couldnapost wait to meet their baby boy and were excited to start a new chapter of their lives.But their world was turned upside down during the pregnancy after discovering their son was going to be born with an extremely rare condition.Doctors confirmed their first child had both hypoplastic left heart syndrome- a birth defect that affects normal blood flow through the heart - and an a trial septal defect , a hole between the two small chambers of the heart.    Ria, , said: Everything was fine from the private -week scan and at the scan at  weeks we were told he was growing great. Then to be told that Leo had these conditions which were so rare we were just in shock. That day our world broke. It was hard to think that we werenapost going to be able to hold Leo when he was born. We just kept being positive and hoping everything would be fine. Requiring immediate surgery at birth, Leo was one of the only babies to be born at the Freeman Hospital via c-section on August  with a full team travelling from the Royal Victoria Infirmary to deliver him. It meant the Newbiggin Hall parents were unable to hold their baby before being whisked off for emergency treatment. It was like he wasnapost actually born, said Ria. It just didnapost feel right. We had to wait seven and a half hours before we got to see him. Despite the surgery being a success, just six days later doctors suspected Leoaposs condition was more uncommon than anticipated with him also believed to have had a lung condition called congenital pulmonary lymphangiectasia.    This, however, was not able to be confirmed due to a Leo not being strong enough for a biopsy to be taken. Ria said: This made Leoaposs case even rarer and our perfect little boy was one of  cases in the world from what we saw online. We read that both conditions are not usually compatible in le. It was on August  when they were told the devastating news that no parent wants to hear - that there was no more doctors could do to save their son. We didnapost speak much in the meeting because I donapost think we knew how to react, said Ria. It wasnapost until we were left alone when we broke down in tears. By that moment it hit us and we knew we werenapost going to be taking our baby boy home. This was heartbreaking news for us as parents and as people who had fought for so long through infertility and IVF to bring our boy into the world and to have to let him go so soon. Tesco workers Ria and Aaron spent the day making special memories with Leo, including holding him for the very first time, before saying their final goodbyes. Ria said: We washed him, dressed him and held him - the things you take for granted. It was the first time that we felt like parents. It was the best and the worst day at the same time.

story: NewsInside Royal Familys Balmoral holiday - with five outfit changes a day and strict scheduleMeghan Markle, Prince Harry, Kate Middleton, the Cambridge kids and Archie Harrison will head up to Scotland to stay with the Queen and Prince Philip over the summer - but what do they do when they get there ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  AUG NewsThe Royal Family have been spending their summers at Balmoral for years "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEvery summer the Queen and other members of the Royal Family head up to Scotland to enjoy some quality time together in the countryside.According to her granddaughter Princess Eugenie, the stunning Balmoral Castle and estate is where the Monarch is the most happy, and stays there for several weeks in August. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their kids George, Charlotte and Louis, Prince Charles, Camilla, Meghan Markle and Prince Harry and the York sisters all pop in to stay with the Queen and Philip during their holidays - making it a very busy time for them.But what exactly do the royals get up to during their Scottish break   Speaking on ITVaposs documentary Our Queen at  Eugenie said: Itaposs the most beautul place on earth. I think Granny is the most happy there, I think she really, really loves the Highlands…walks, picnics, dogs, a lot of dogs, thereaposs always dogs, and people coming in and out all the time. Family-wise weaposre all there, so itaposs a lovely base for Granny and Grandpa to be - for us to come and see them up there where you just have room to breathe and run. But according to an insider, itaposs not almost the most relaxing break and things can be pretty hectic. They told Vanity Fair: “It can get quite busy at what they call ‘the big house’ and it’s not especially relaxing even though it’s a holiday.    “There’s a daily routine which evolves around meal times, several outfit changes every day, sometimes five, and the Queen likes everything to run like clockwork. The focus is on being outdoors and in the countryside walking, grousing, fishing and hunting.” Balmoral is a working estate with highlights including grouse moors, the lush green forests and farmland, as well as plenty of animals from the herds of deer to Highland cattle and ponies. The Royals love grouse hunting, and go out regularly during their time at the castle.    Prince Charles, William, Harry and Kate have all been known to go out shooting over the summer months, and last year they even took little George along to watch.But itaposs bad news for the family this year as the Queen has been forced to call off the whole grouse shooting season as there has been a drop in the number of the birds in the area due to insects and bad  weather . Photographer Milton Gendel said he was invited to Balmoral back in  , and opened up about the experience to  Vanity Fair  .   He wrote: On some days there were excursions into the country. The Queen had been taught to drive by auxiliary army officers during World War II, and she handled a Land Rover with intrepid skill on the hilly and winding roads. When we went riding, she saddled her horse, and afterward carried the saddle back to the stable herself. At a shoot on the grounds a truck delivered a sumptuous buffet lunch. The aposgunsapos lay on the grass for a postprandial respite.

Until last Friday, I had no facilities and had nowhere to wash our dishes and cups. I have had to rinse them in the bath. I have had to have appliances redelivered more than once because I was told theyaposd be able to be installed.  As a result, Margaret says she has had to live with boxes of kitchen items throughout her house. She said: I had  items delivered for the kitchen. All my living things, such pots and pans are living room and bedroom areas and there is no space to live in. I canapost get in my garage, which is packed with items for the kitchen items. The floor had to be re-levelled but it wasnapost done right, so I have had to pay thousands of pounds for an independent builder to do the work.  I paid for a breakfast bar - they donapost know where that is. I have the legs for it, but not the bar. I had to buy a picnic table because I was having friends over and didnapost have anywhere to eat. New items that have been fitted have also been ruined, she said. My new sink unit has been damaged, I had a new boiler cabinet made but that was blocked in so I had to have that removed, she said.  I have no doors or toilet door and the toilet is filled with boxes. The fiasco has had a detrimental impact on Margaretaposs health, she said. Every time I speak to someone they are either away or holiday, she said. I collapsed on Sunday because of the stress because my heart rate went funny. I was out for a few minutes, luckily my daughter is trained first aider.  A spokesperson from Magnet said it was a complex case because a lot of the customer concerns raised involve additional works contracted independently and aren’t related to Magnet. They added: The list supplied by the customer isn’t an indication of poor work, it shows a list of what’s not been completed “Having said that, we want to make sure all our customers receive the highest level of service, which is partly how we were awarded the number one spot within the recent Which  guide to kitchens.

title: meet brit family trying save
story: NewsMeet the Brit family trying to save struggling teens on brink of suicideEXCLUSIVE: Dave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, are part of a small army of volunteers for mental health charity Shout, which since launching in May has held more than , conversations - % mentioning suicide, % depression and % self-harmShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, are part of a small army of volunteers for mental health charity Shout "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe silence around the kitchen table hangs heavy, punctuated only by the rapid drone of typing across three laptops, and the  intermittent ‘ping’ of messages. Leo the dog scuffles across the floor, maybe wondering when the normal Tuesday evening bustle of cooking tea, and watching Love Island, will begin. It’ll be an hour or so. Dave Bush, we Sue, and daughter Jess, have suspended family le, as they do once or twice a week, to simultaneously chat, via text messages, to complete strangers. Beneath the hush, there’s a lot of noise – fraught words tumbling out in -character snippets strung together in anxious streams, which need every ounce of their attention. As we sit here drinking tea, two of those strangers texting Sue and Jess are revealing they are suicidal.  Sue is chatting to a school-age teenager. “They are struggling, they have been self-harming, they’ve mentioned bullying, and they’ve said they feel suicidal,” she relays, hurriedly looking up for a second as she waits for a reply. Sitting next to her, Jess explains: “My person’s introductory message said they were suicidal. They have a plan, they say they also have the means, but an idea of timeframe isn’t clear yet.” She’s waiting for a reply to tell herit’s tonight. They tell me this situation is far from rare. “It’s a reasonably common conversation to have,” Sue says. “Especially in the evening.” This is Shout, the UK’s first free   text service open to anyone in crisis, run by Mental Health Innovations, and launched in May by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, as a means to tackle Britain’s mental health crisis. And crisis it is, according to the figures. In its pilot year, Shout, which has , UK volunteers answering texts, handled , conversations. Today, they’re fielding around  a day. Since its official launch in May, it has held more than ,. Of those, % have mentioned suicide, % depression and % self-harm.  While almost half of texters are aged -, disturbingly, % are aged -. Figures from the annual Good Childhood report this week revealed more children aged - saying they are unhappy than at any point in the last  years. The Bushes, from Cheddington, Bucks, are Shout’s only volunteer family. It helps that they can hold conversations side by side, because it’s heavy going. Sue and Dave joined up in December, and Jess in March, and when we meet, they have held over  conversations. I join them at pm on a weekday. Shout’s busiest time is between pm and am but even in this moment there are  conversations unfolding, plus a queue of four people waiting. When users first text, a complex algorithm assessesthey are high risk. Shout’s volunteers, who have undergone  to  hours of training, are monitored by remote supervisors. Sue, , who works in business development, plucks her school-age teen from the queue, but they take a while to respond to her.  Because they’ve mentioned suicide, she needs to risk assess them, and the wait for a reply is an anxious one. At the sound of a ping she snaps back to her screen. “We have the volume set loud,” she apologises. Meanwhile, Dave, , an actuary, has started chatting. His text is from a young woman struggling as counselling she has been having has ended. But it’s accountant Jess, , who’s found herself confronted with the most immediately challenging situation. Her texter has said they are suicidal right now. The risk assessment has stages, including discovering whether the texter has a plan for suicide, and the means, such as pills or razor blades, whether they have that means with them, and how soon they plan to act. They eventually reply they want to talk to someone about their feelings – a service Shout doesn’t provide. “I have suggested the Samaritans,” says Jess, now waiting anxiously to hearthe texter has called them. In this case, the scenario is made simpler because the texter knows what they need. Dave has experienced a couple where an “active rescue” was needed and emergency services were called. They account for % of conversations. For the first time, I see him become emotional. “They told me they could not keep themselves safe,” he says. “They were self-harming as well.

title: student who wasnt used drinking
story: NewsStudent who wasnt used to drinking drowned in uni lake after downing JagerbombsDaniel Williams, , died after going missing during a night out on Reading University campusShareCommentsByCharlie Moloney:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDaniel was extremely popular with friends and had only started drinking when he was  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student not used to drinking alcohol drowned in a freezing lake on his campus after downing four Jagerbombs, an inquest heard. Daniel Williams was not a regular drinker and he usually the one helping others to find their way home whenthey had drunk a bit too much, the coroner heard. Tragically there was nobody to take the -year-old home on a night when he appeared like a zombie, having consumed two-and-half times the drink-drive limit at the University of Readingaposs student bar. Mr Williams, known to friends as Dan, attempted to make his way home alone through five inches of fresh snow in the early hours of January . He had become separated from his friends but in his drunken state he accidentally plunged into the icy waters of the Whiteknights lake in Reading, Berks, the coroner ruled.  He was found following an extensive police search, in which boat crews and dog units were sent out. Scores of officers struggled to break the thick ice on top of the lake, just hundreds of yards away from the student union block, so they could enter the chest-high water. The inquest heard that ironically, Daniel was a leguard. The temperature was -C when they waded through treacle-like silt, searching for the missing student. The search ended days later - on February  - when Danaposs body was found, face down with his lower body submerged in the water and his mobile phone and wallet still in his pockets, the inquest in Reading, Berks, heard.  Heidi Connor, Senior Coroner for Berkshire, told the inquest: It seems to me that the circumstances of Danaposs death are tragic but very clear. On the night of January , he went out with friends, doing what students do around the world: he was enjoying himself, drinking alcohol at the student club. He came late in le to alcohol. Drinking alcohol when you are not used to drinking alcohol can have a more dramatic effect, she said. The inquest heard evidence from William Collins, who was one of three other young men who lived with Daniel in their student lodgings near to the university. Mr Collins told the inquest how the four housemates had decided on a night out together on January  and had left their home at pm. He said Daniel, who was wearing a dark-coloured hooded top, had been with him in the Cheese Room, the main dance floor in the newly-refurbished sixty nightclub and bar during the weekly Wednesday Union night. Daniel had ordered four Jagerbombs, a mixture of Jagermeister and an energy drink, for himself, the inquest heard, before he disappeared.  Mr Collins said, in an interview given to police before Daniel was found: It is normal behaviour for Daniel to just go off and leave us during a night and he had done this several times before. We did not see him again. The second year computer sciences student, rom Sutton, Surrey, was later seen by another student, Rebecca Jones. She saw him standing near to the front of the dance floor in the Cheese Room and clinging onto a railing in front of the DJ. Ms Jones said: I saw he was very blank in his face, ashe was staring at us. It appeared ashe was a zombie andyou jumped at him he would not have moved. Nobody saw Daniel leave the student bar and by the evening of January , his housemates had become so concerned they contacted the police and reported him as missing. Detective Constable Andy Matheson, of Thames Valley Police, told the inquest police had upgraded Mr Williams to a high-risk missing person after failing to find him during an overnight search. He told the inquest police had established Mr Williams had left the student bar at .am, as his phone had disconnected from the unionaposs Wi-Fi network and his phone had stopped receiving any signal at .am.  Det. Con. Matheson said: I donapost think anything can be read into that as to when Dan entered the lake.The phone still ed when it came out of the lake. It is possible it [the phone] could still have been connected to the network while it was submerged in the water. Danielaposs parents organised a huge leaflet drop around the university area, appealing for any information about the whereabouts of the blond-haired, blue-eyed student. Volunteers from the local Lowland Search Team also took part in picking through bushes and undergrowth in the hope of finding Daniel and crews from the Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service used their fire boat and waders to search in the lake, three times without success. Police Constable Al Mathieson, leading the search on the ground, said the conditions at the lake, which was not especially deep but was frozen solid and surrounded by a thick layer of silt, meant the focus of the search was on the bank of the lake. Mr Williams was found just shy of an island, which is about  metres from the bank of the lake and the inquest heard the joint investigations of the police and the coroneraposs office discovered there was no sign of any third party involvement, nor any indication that Daniel had been planning to take his own le.  Mrs Connor told his family, who attended the inquest, the young student had no drugs in his system but did have mg of alcohol per ml of blood, two-and-a-half times the drink-driving limit. The coroner said: He did have a relatively high blood alcohol level. In this line of work, I have seen worse than this, but it is undoubtedly high. A post mortem examination gave the cause of death as drowning while under the influence of alcohol and Mrs Connor suggested to the family Mr Williamsapos death should be ruled as an accident. In response, a woman believed to be Danielaposs mother, told the coroner: Contrary to the findings that he had the alcohol, ironically Dan wasnapost a drinker and I feel he was possibly rather naive. Two-and-a-half times the legal limit for driving is a lot, but as you say, there are people who drink a lot more. He did not drink at all until he was  years old. He was a wonderful son. He was genuine, principled, universally loved and liked by everyone who knew him.Ironically, he worked as a le guard. I feel it is tragic because I do not feel that his death should define him, because we are heartbroken.I just hope he did not suffer. Mrs Connor responded: I doubt there is one person in this room who has not been under the influence of alcohol at some point in their le. It certainly does not define Daniel in any way, shape or form.It is just so very sad that this was the outcome in Danaposs case.

It could be a major Category  storm when it makes a direct hit late Sunday or early Monday and a powerful Category  hurricane when it passes through the Orlando area. Residents have been told to prepare for the worst and holidaymakersapos plans have been thrown into uncertainty, with Walt Disney World telling visitors to keep checking local weather reports. Has your holiday been disrupted by Hurricane Dorian  Email webnews@mirror.    So far the theme park is due to open as scheduled as visitors celebrate the opening of the Star Wars: Galaxyaposs Edge attraction. Dorianaposs main threats are likely to be mph winds, up to ins of rain, a coastal storm surge, flash flooding, huge waves and rip currents.    Florida Governor Ron DeSantis warned all residents on the stateaposs east coast to plan for a disaster and stock up on seven days of supplies, including food, water and medicine. Dorian also threatens to disrupt flights and cruise ship journeys. The spaceport in Cape Canaveral began its hurricane preparations on Wednesday.    Dorian - currently a Category  storm - was about  miles north-west of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Thursday morning after sideswping the Caribbean without any major damage. The storm is expected to become a major hurricane on Friday as it moves well east of the Bahamas, which could see up to ins of rain and flash flooding. title: bard of salford john cooper clarke promises a right good night in dundee visit
story: John Cooper Clarke is ready to rock# and Dundee should be afraid, very afraid.He may be in his older years, but he is not holding back.And the man known as the punk poet has vowed to perform in his unmistakable style – machine gun delivery studded with factory floor language.The rasping Salford accent is still there and the humour as cutting as a surgeon’s scalpel.And for the real devotees, John has teased them by telling the Tele exclusively that he has begun planning his memoirs.In typical fashion he says: “I haven’t kept a f****** diary, but I have got a good memory.“In fact, my memory is long and my vengeance is total.”To the musicians and celebs who have crossed JCC in the past, start praying now because the master could even recall the gig I saw him perform at Strathclyde University in the early s and who was playing on the same bill.For the record, it was Siouxsie and the Banshees – and I couldn’t remember that, despite being a few years younger than the man.Back in the day, John easily recalls everyone being angry young men and women. The hate for Thatcher was pure and the depth of feeling surged through concerts and rallies.He says with a chuckle: “Them were the days.“We thought it was bad then, but everything can get worse, as we see now. It’s a case of careful what you wish for.“I don’t get involved in politics now, like I say when didn’t anyone complain about politicians “Can you point me to a golden era where# everybody liked being ruled  F***ing never!“But there are some real creeps nowadays. But then again I expect the worst from any politician.”So what can fans in Dundee expect when John rolls into town for his show at the city’s Gardyne Theatre on Saturday October  Without missing a beat he fires back: “A right f****** good night!“And they can expect more of the same#and then some. There will be a few classics and there will maybe be a few extra poems.“Then I will add a bit of fun and I can guarantee – solid, copper-plated guarantee – that everybody is going to leave with a smile on their face.”John has fond memories of Dundee and spoke of savouring the atmosphere of a waterfront hotel and added: “I love coming to Scotland and Dundee. I’ve been many times and the reaction of the crowd is great.“I was here last year and saw the VA which is fabulous. I know of DC Thomson and the Sunday Post, the Beano and the Dandy plus Oor Wullie.“Maybe I will buy one of those sculptures.”Posh hotels and venues seem a world away from the clubs and student venues of the s with smoke-filled rooms and plastic tumblers full of warm beer.He used to travel to the shows on public transport and chuckles at the memory.John said: “Yeah, long time ago now, mate. Now I have a driver and I am too old for public transport.“But I still love doing live gigs. It’s smashing. Anywhere where there’s people is greatI’m doing my stuff.“I am working on my book of poems right now. It’s called ‘The Luckiest Man Alive’ and I’m also working on the memoirs. vw, px"  “I am thinking of calling that ‘I Wanna Be Yours’ after the Arctic Monkeys. I just hope to live long enough to finish it.“But I am not finishing up any time soon. I have never even thought about that. I am not retiring, not yet and not in the foreseeable future.”John has the tour to contend with first and is also lining up some television work.And at the age of  there is definitely no holding him back. So look out for many more tours to come from the man who wants to be yours.
