title: £81k for repairs to Newcastle church
story: PRIORITY repairs to one of Newcastlersquos oldest churches will be funded by a grant of just over pound, from the National Lottery Heritage Fund.The spire and tower of St Johnrsquos Church of Ireland church will receive essential repairs.The  year-old church, situated overlooking the South Promenade, needed work to repair rain water ingress into the spire and tower.Canon Ian Ellis, church rector, said that the generous grant of pound, was made possible by money raised by National Lottery players and generously supported by the church parishioners.He continued: ldquoWe are thrilled to have received this support with thanks to the National Lottery players and are confident the project will enhance the church and sustain it for the use of all people for the foreseeable future.Supported through the National Lottery Heritage Fund, work has started to prevent the constant flow of rain water into the churchrsquos spire and tower.This ingress of water has already created internal damage to the inside of the spire, tower, bell  and the main entrance.Canon Ellis added: ldquoIf the problem was not addressed it would have led to a possible collapse of the spire and hence closure of the church.ldquoIt is planned that the repair project will be completed by the end of October. This will ensure that this important local landmark will be secure for generations to come and visitors to the town can continue to enjoy it as a back.The parishrsquos project convenor, Dennis Constable said: ldquoThis repair work will ensure that people will still be able to visit the church and enjoy looking at the heritage and the wonderful stained glass windows.ldquoThe church also holds many treasures of history that stretch back in Newcastlersquos history and which are relevant to many people.He added: ldquoThe repairs, which include the bell tower  will provide for the church bells, which have been silent for so long, to once again to be rung..prettyPhoto

title: Border Cup set to start
story: CUP action continues to dominate the local soccer scene with the countdown to Christmas joy beginning on Saturday.Thatrsquos when the first round of the prestigious Border Cup takes place with eight local teams in action.Top billing goes to the game at Robert Adams Park between Kilmore Rec and Portaferry.Other ties include Grove United v Killyleagh YC, Drumaness Mills v Greenisland, Holywood FC v Ballynahinch Olympic, Aquinas v Ballynahinch United, Comber Rec v Bangor Swts and Saintfield United v Bryansburn Rangers. Downpatrick FC, Newcastle and Dromara Village all received byes.Kilmore manager John Young will be hoping for a change of fortune when the Rec entertain Portaferry.Kilmore, who have yet to field at full strength this season and who havenrsquot started with the same  players in any of their five games, will be confident of opening their account at the expense of their Division B opponents.The Rec will still be without their GAA players and Portaferry will never get a better chance to claim a notable scalp.Elsewhere, Ballynahinch Olympic, beaten on penalties in last yearrsquos final by Crumlin Star, are expected to progress at Holywoodrsquos expense, while Paul Sharvinrsquos Killyleagh outfit will do well to get a result at Grove United, who have made a good start to le in Division A following their promotion at the end of last season.The third round of the Steel and Sons Cup and the first round of the Junior Cup take place on Saturday, September .Only three local teams have made it through to the third round of the Steel and Sons Cup with Ballynahinch Olympic entertaining Oliver Plunkett, Comber Rec are at home to Ballynure Old Boys and Crewe United are visitors to The Showgrounds to take on Killyleagh.Fewer teams than usual have entered the Junior Cup with Castlewellan v Sandy Row and Rathfriland Rangers v Cleary Celtic the only local teams involved in first round action.The second round of the Tennents Irish Cup and the first round of the County Antrim Junior Shield will take place on Saturday, September , with the following games:Irish CupComber Rec v Coagh United, Killyleagh YC v Downshire Young Men, Newcastle v Banbridge Town, Rathfriland Rangers v Seagoe and Richill v Valley Rangers.Junior Shield -- Kelvin Old Boys v Dundrum United, FC Whiteabbey v Comber Rec II, Saintfield United II v Men for God United, Carryduff Athletic v Southside Rangers, Mourne Rovers v Corrymeela, St Lukersquos v Celtic Bhoys, Kircubbin v Crewe United II, Castle Star II v Killyleagh YC II, Newcastle Swts v Glanville Rec, th Newtownabbey v Castlewellan, Comber Young Men v Rathcoole FC.Dromara Village II, Tollymore United, Ballyvea, Ballynahinch Olympic Town, Rossglass County, Comber Star, Kilmore Rec Swts, Carryduff Colts, Ballynahinch Young Men and Ardglass all received first round byes..prettyPhoto

title: Bright are relentless as Saints bow out
story: Bright -St Michaelrsquos -PARADOR LODGE JFCBRIGHT booked their place in the last eight against Aghaderg with a disciplined win over St Michaelrsquos at Drumgath on Saturday.Joe McIlduff gave St Michaelrsquos the lead with a point in the first minute, but this proved to be their only score of the half.Bright dominated matters in and around the middle of the park and points from B J McMenamin, Conor Doyle and Rian Tempanyand a predatory goal from Freddie OrsquoConnor gave Kyran Smythrsquos side a - to - lead.St Michaelrsquos also took the first score of the second half through Kevin Leatham, but this only served to waken Bright up and points from Matthew Burns and Tempany had the East Down side - to - ahead.Niall Hanna and Tempany and Leatham and Freddie OrsquoConnor exchanged points before Niall Marsden threw a spanner in the works when he drilled the ball to the back of the Bright net and leave six points in it, - to -.This was the last score for St Michaelrsquos as Bright closed up shop and took the spoils with points from Tempanyand Declan Trainor..prettyPhoto

title: Call for 30mph speed limit in Clanvaraghan
story: A CALL to reduce the speed limit in Clanaghan to mph has been made by South Down MP Chris Hazzard.Mr Hazzard has asked the Department for InfrastructureRoads to reduce the speed limit in Clanaghan following concerns that traffic is presenting an increasingly dangerous problem for a growing population.Following a door to door community survey with Slieve Croob councillor Roisin Howell and Emma Rogan MLA, Mr Hazzard said the issue needed to be addressed.He stressed that a child hit by a car travelling at mph had just a % chance of surviving whereas survival increased signicantly to %the speed was at mph.ldquoMake no mistake about it, this is absolutely a le or death issue, he said.ldquoSpeaking to residents in the village, itrsquos clear that patience is coming to an end and local families want to see DFI Roads take the appropriate action by lowering the speed limit from the existing mph to mph.He explained that Clanaghan had experienced a signicant growth in its population in recent years and the addition of a large new housing development, meant there are now more young families living in the village.He said: ldquoWe believe the case for reducing the speed limit in Clanaghan is very strong mdash especially when you also bear in mind that all the neighbouring villages of similar size enjoy the additional road safety benefits of mph speed limits. ldquoMs Rogan said: ldquoWe have launched a new campaign reminding drivers to be aware of their speed whilst travelling through our local rural villages.ldquoIt only takes a moment to lose concentration on the road, but the consequences can last a letime. Please drive with care at all times..prettyPhoto

title: Controversy reigns as ‘Islanders falter
story: Loughinisland -Mayobridge -MORGAN FUELS SFCMAYOBRIDGE are becoming the great escape artists after denying Loughinisland a quarter-final place at a sun-kissed Castlewellan on Saturday with a late winner in extra timeJust as in the first round win over Burren, Mayobridge were staring defeat in the face, but they are now thriving on adversity and overturned a - to - lead in the second period of extra-time to run out one-point winners.Caolan Gallagher fisted Mayobridge into an early lead and Conleth OrsquoHare followed this up in the second minute with another point. Loughinisland kept plugging away and were rewarded in the sixth minute with a penalty after a Mayobridge defender was adjudged to have blocked a shot with his foot.Stefan Mason was coolness personied as he drilled the spot kick high into the net and give his side a - to - lead.Stefan followed up his penalty with a rsquo before Corey Quinn netted at the other end to give the lsquoBridge a - to - lead after  minutes.The game continued to flow from end-to-end and two unanswered points from Jonny Flynn and a Rory Mason free had Loughinisland back in front with a - to - lead.Mayobridge responded with a point from Cathal Magee, but Jody Gormleyrsquos men finished the half on top and points from Stefan Mason and Conor Megoran sent them in at the break with a - to - lead at the break.Rory Mason extended that lead to three points at the start of the second half, but OrsquoHare kept Mayobridge in touch with his second point of the day.Megoran and Quinn, Stefan Mason and OrsquoHare and Quinn and Rory Mason swapped scores before Stefan Mason and Dean McLaughlin pointed the Blues into a - to - lead with only a few minutes remaining.Anyone who thought that Mayobridge were dead and buried were forced to think again as a point from OrsquoHare and a goal in the sixth minute of added time from Jamie McKay sent the game to extra-time.Loughinisland held a three-point advantage going into the second period of extra-time after Dan Gordon and Stefan Mason swapped points with Quinn.Mayobridge kept chipping away at Loughinislandrsquos lead and somehow dragged the game from the fire at the death to break Loughinislandrsquos hearts..prettyPhoto

title: Down house prices have biggest increase in UK
story: DOWN house prices are proving to be the most buoyant in the UK, according to the latest House Price Index.The Newry Mourne and Down area performed twice as well as other Northern Ireland council areas and had biggest increase in the UK mdash a healthy % hike on last year.An average three-bedroom semi-detached house in Newry, Mourne and Down now sells for around pound,.Across Northern Ireland the average house price saw an increase of .% over the last year, with an average three-bed semi selling for around pound, ndash overall a . % hike on  prices.Lisburn and Castlereagh still remain the the best performing district, with a three bed semi attracting an average pice of pound, mdash a .% increase mdash closely followed by Ards and North Down, which had a . % increase on last year.Mary-Lou Press, a partner at Alexander Reid  Frazer Estate Agents in Downpatrick, said: ldquoWe have certainly noticed house prices in the area increasing over the past year as demand outstrips supply.ldquoWith the increase in prices and the level of interest we are seeing from potential buyers, more sellers will be attracted to the market leading to continued growth for the remainder of the year.Miss Press, who is also the NAEA Propertymark Regional Executive for Northern Ireland, added: ldquoThis area offers better value for money and the process is more affordable.ldquoSpecically in relation to value for money, transport links for those commuting into Belfast and the South East make the area one of the best places to live.Describing other factors which may have contributed to the buoyant house prices, Miss Press said: ldquoThe latest health inequalities report, published by the Department of Health last month suggested le expectancy ies across the five Northern Irish health trusts.ldquoA manrsquos overall le expectancy in Northern Ireland is . years. However, in the South East Trust we seem to be bucking the trend and can expect a promising . years mdash the highest le expectancy in Northern Ireland.ldquoThe picture is the same for women. The female average across the Northern Ireland is . years and women living in the South Eastern Trust areas enjoying . years mdash again the highest in the province..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre serves up new sport
story: A NEW sport is set to make its debut at the Down Leisure Centre in Downpatrick this autumn. From September , pickleball sessions will take place every Wednesday between .am and .pm.Pickleball is a paddleball sport that combines elements of tennis, badminton, and table tennis. Two or four players use solid paddles made of wood or composite materials to hit a perforated polymer ball over a net.The sport provides a good aerobic workout and can be enjoyed by all ages and skill levels. While the rules are simple and the game easy for beginners to learn, it can develop into a quick, fast-paced, competitive game for experienced players.Newry, Mourne and Down Council vice-chairman, Terry Andrews, said the local authority Council is delighted to bring new initiatives to the district that will help people integrate physical activity into their everyday routines.ldquoOur sport and leisure department, through its lsquoBe Activersquo campaign, is keen focus on providing our residents with new and interesting ways to lead healthier and happier lives, he explained.ldquoIntroducing pickleball to our leisure centres is one such scheme and I am certain it will prove a real hit. Be active your way every day is our goal for all the citizens across the district and wider area.The lsquoBe Activersquo campaign is an integral component of the local authorityrsquos corporate plan commitments to develop key infrastructure that will improve leisure centres and introduce new activities that can be accessed by all.The pickleball sessions will be part of the lsquoeverybody active programmersquo and each session costs pound per person..prettyPhoto

title: Fresh bid to solve traffic congestion
story: ROADS officials have this week been urged to finally crack town centre traffic congestion in Downpatrick.Senior engineers from the Department for Infrastructure have been invited to sit down with local councillors to discuss the issue and look at innovative ways of addressing a problem which many believe is impacting on the townrsquos economy.A meeting with engineers is part of a two-pronged approach suggested by local councillor Dermot Curran, who also wants MLAs to take up the mantle and raise the issue with the government departmentrsquos permanent secretary.The councillor is concerned that while congestion problems in other major towns across the country have been addressed, there has been no signicant progress in Downpatrick.Roads officials have come up with what has been described as a short, medium and long term strategy to deal with the congestion issue. Work to widen Fountain Street to provide on-street parking and traffic calming measures has already been completed, while a pound, project at Collinsrsquo Corner is currently underway.Roads officials have previously suggested the introduction of a one-way system but little or nor progress appears to have been made on this particular scheme.While pleased with the work in Fountain Street and Collinsrsquo Corner, Cllr Curran believes they will not have a positive impact on town centre congestion, prompting his call to meet with senior roads engineers. He is also concerned that no progress is being made to tackle a congestion and road safety issue at Edward Street in the town.His call for talks to discuss solutions to town centre congestion came ahead of a special meeting between councillors and roads officials last night when the Department of Infrastructure presented its annual report which details work that has already been completed on ious schemes and what projects are in the pipeline.Cllr Curran said the annual report contained no ldquoconcrete proposals for addressing town centre congestion, prompting his call to meet with engineers.ldquoA proposed road between Irish Street and St Patrickrsquos Avenue has been shelved due to the cost involved and the minimal impact it would have on tackling congestion, he said. ldquoThat is why we need to get round the table and look at all options moving forward.ldquoCan lessons be learned from other towns which experienced similar problems or what about changing the sequencing of traffic lights  he asked.ldquoIt has been said many times that there is no quick fix solution to Downpatrickrsquos congestion problem and while the layout of the town may pose problems for engineers, surely it is time for some innovative thinking ldquoAll the key players need to get together as years of inaction has exacerbated the congestion nightmare faced by residents, businesses and visitors.Cllr Curran says the time has come to ldquograsp the congestion nettle with the onus on roads officials to finally deliver by taking a critical look at the problems.ldquoWe need to take a critical look at the problem and come up with ideas on the way forward. I suspect that the congestion issue that we have in Downpatrick would not be allowed to go unaddressed in any other major town in the country. We have had numerous reports on the way forward but what people, in particular those in the business community what to see, is action, he continued.ldquoDownpatrick councillors need to join forces and sit down with roads engineers to look at what can be done. Apart from the development of the Saul Way link road, there has been no major traffic development in Downpatrick town centre for decades.ldquoThe congestion problem is getting worse andthe ambitious plans to redevelop the former Irish Street police station base and adjoining buildings are to be a success and attract new commercial and private development, we need to solve the traffic problem.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThe congestion is driving shoppers out of the town and we need to arrest this decline. To achieve this, I believe that we need a brainstorming sessions to come up with a new blueprint on the way forward. There must be an end to a congestion problem blighting the local economy..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C August 28%2C 1979
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash A young Ballynahinch familyrsquos seven-month ordeal ended yesterday mdash only hours after the Down Recorder took up their case.Thatrsquos how long the McGrory family have been waiting for a new fireplace in the living room of their Housing Executive house at Windmill Gardens.After such a long wait, workmen finally arrived out yesterday afternoon, less than  hours after the Recorder had contacted Housing Executive headquarters about the situation.The problems for the family started three years ago when their fireplace broke up. Housing Executive workmen carried out repairs, but seven months ago the fireplace again broke up. Since then repeated calls to the Executive met with little or no response.ldquoWith winter fast coming we needed this fireplace fixed, said Mr Terry McGrory. ldquoDuring the summer months we managed to make do, but therersquos no way we could face cold nights without a fire in our living room.ldquoSince February wersquove had to do without a fire and it was beginning to look like it wouldnrsquot be fixed at all. Wersquove called on the Housing Executive numerous times and used up all the repair forms at the back of our rent book, but still no-one had it fixed.Mrs Mildred Terry was equally unhappy. ldquoThe last time they came to fix the fireplace three years ago, they simply pushed it back against the wall and plastered it over the wallpaper which we had just put on, she said.ldquoIt became a big nuisance having to hope that friendly neighbours would help us wash our clothes and provide us with baths, because we were unable to heat our water by the use of the fire.BISHOPSCOURT mdash Police are investigating the circumstances leading to the death of an RAF sergeant at Bishopscourt last Tuesday evening. The sergeant was seen running into bushes at the camp and two shots were heard. He was found later with two gunshot wounds to the head. The manrsquos name is not being released until the next of kin have been informed.CASTLEWELLAN mdash The people of Castlewellan paid tribute to one of their doctors, who retired recently, with a special presentation iety concert in St Malachyrsquos High School last Tuesday night.Dr Brendan Moore, who first came to the town in , received several gts from the people after many of the townrsquos top entertainers had put on a rousing concert on his behalf.Dr Moore set up his practice in Upper Square, but later moved to there present residence in Circular Road where he continued to give his valuable help.Mr Patrick McAleenan, principal of St Malachyrsquos High School, introduced the presentations. Mrs Josephine King, on behalf of the people, presented Dr Moore with an inscribed watch and a cheque and Mrs Moore with an inscribed watch, while Miss Una Hardy presented Mrs Moore with a bouquet of flowers.Dr Moore thanked everyone for their generosity and stressed how much he had enjoyed practising in the Castlewellan area for so many years.SAINTFIELD mdash Residents beside a quarry near Saintfield who frequently had windows broken in their homes when blasting took place had their grievances aired at a recent meeting of Castlereagh Borough Council.A local councillor, Mr J A Lowe, raised complaints of householders whose windows are shattered by blasting at Lisdoonan Quarry.Mr Lowe said residents had suffered from broken windows and undue noise on many occasions. He wanted to knowplanning permission covered the size of explosives used in the quarry.He was told that  conditions were attached to the planning permission, covering such issues as the size of explosive charges and the permitted distance from the nearest dwellings.KILLYLEAGH mdash Work on a major housing redevelopment programme in Killyleagh is in danger of grinding to a halt. Speculation is mounting that the main contractors are getting ready to pull out because of unpaid bills by the Housing Executive.Ten houses which have been virtually complete for six months are still lying idle because minor sub-contract work has not been started. Ten families, who were told last December that new homes would be ready by February, are still waiting and the situation is fast becoming a deadlock.The poundm redevelopment scheme at Irish Street was to have been a Housing Executive showpiece. Work began on building  new homes in two phases in . The scheme had been designed to ldquoretain the character and charm of Killyleagh, transforming the old houses into modern housing for some  people.The Housing Executive have flatly refused to comment on the latest developments at the site and they will not go into the many complaints, except to admit that there are problems at the site.Three weeks ago a major row erupted all over the province when a dispute in the Executiversquos finance department caused a backlog of payments to dozens of small construction firms.DOWNPATRICK mdash A group of residents in the Flying Horse housing estate in Downpatrick are campaigning for proper dustbins to be provided.At present residents are supplied with paper bags which they say are too small and do not hold any great weight of refuse. They cannot be use for ashes, which residents must pile up in their back gardens.Their campaign has been taken up by Mr Raymond Blaney, of Republican Clubs the Workersrsquo Party. ldquoWhen it rains heavily the bags fall apart and the rubbish is scattered all over the place. Often dogs tear the bags apart with the same results, he said.ldquoThe Flying Horse residents are at a loss to know why Model Farm, a much more recent estate, is supplied with proper metal dustbins while they must do with a totally inadequate paper bag system.STRANGFORD mdash The first ever Strangford Festival went down a smash hit success and the town vibrated with fun and laughter over four days.The festival kicked off on Friday evening with a band parade and carried over the whole bank holiday weekend, culminating with a dance on Monday. The Festival Queen was  year-old Colette Masterson, from Coney Island, Ardglass.Events over the four days included a five-a-side football, childrenrsquos fancy dress, junior showtime, tug of war, darts finals, egg and spoon races, a barbecue and gymkhana.NEWCASTLE mdash Newcastle Technical School was a hive of industry on Saturday morning mdash not with students ing a week early to their studies, but with exhibitors making their plants, flowers, fruit and vegetables ready for the judges at Newcastle and District Horticultural Societyrsquos fourth annual show.The competition was extremely keen in each class and it is to the credit of the members of the society that they have established such an interesting and colourful show in such a short time.PORTAFERRY mdash There have been several inquiries, but no firm offers for the Portaferry Hotel, which is up for sale. The estate agents, Sidney Mawhinney in Lisburn, remained tight-lipped about the price which the hotel, one of the provincersquos leading waterfront inns, is expected to fetch.GAA mdash Ballycran regained the Down senior hurling title with a - to - victory over Ballygalget at St Patrickrsquos Park, Portaferry on Sunday.It was Ballycranrsquos th victory and although the final scoreline would suggest they had an easy passage it would not be entirely indicative of Ballygalgetrsquos fine performance.But for two brilliant saves by Ballycran keeper Noel Keith, the winning margin would have been much smaller..prettyPhoto

title: Fundraiser in tribute to racing icon Brian
story: THE Brian Steenson Memorial Group is hosting a fundraising car and motorcycle cavalcade in Crossgar next Sunday.Owners of cars and motorcycles of any age are welcome to attend the September  event which the memorial group is organising in conjunction with the Crossgar Community Association as a tribute to the Killyleagh rider who died at the Isle of Man TT races  years ago.Participants are asked to meet from pm at Central Garages at Killyleagh Street in the village with the cavalcade due to move off at pm.A yard adjacent to the Corner Inn and the wide footpath in front of the premises will be used to park motorbikes and scooters. The Ronnie Donnan Memorial Cup will be awarded to the most interesting motorcycle or scooter.The pound entry fee includes and exhibitor food ticket, while single food tickets can also be bought for pound. Tea and sandwiches will be served at pm in the Corner Inn Lounge.Next Sunday, there will be a range of vehicles on display dating from the roaring twenties, forties, fties swinging sixties, seventies and eighties, right up to modern day classics.Graham Ritchie will be displaying photographs and memorabilia of Steenson and Trevor Lindsay will have the riders Aermacchi machine on display which Steenson rode in the   seasons.Earlier this year, the Brian Steenson Memorial Group outlined plans to create a new memorial to the popular motorcycle racer in Killyleagh and a wall mural in Crossgar.Next weekendrsquos car and motorcycle cavalcade sets off at pm for a short run over to Killyleagh with the procession making its way along High Street, Shore Street, Shore Road and the Shanes Lough Road before beginning thejourney to Crossgar.Photographs of the vehicle cavalcade will be taken along the Shore Road in Killyleagh where Strangford Lough provides a stunning back.The memorial group is working hard to remember their motorcycle hero who died at the Nobles Hospital on the Isle of Man in June  five days after his third lap crash crash competing on a Seeley cc machine in the Senior TT.Steensonrsquos parents, Alex and Rita, are both deceased but the rider has five cousins who are fully supportive of our plans to have Brian remembered next year.At the time of Steensonrsquos tragic death, his parents had moved to the Derryboy Road outside Crossgar. The rider was laid to rest at First Killyleagh Presbyterian Church in Plantation Street.World champion Giacomo Agostini and road racers from across the world attended his funeral which was one of the largest ever held in the district.The motorsport enthusiasts behind the memorial plan are committed to doing everything they can for a road racer they have described as a ldquoone of lersquos gentlemen.Next weekendrsquos cavalcade is the latest fundraising event to raise the cash they require to make their dream a reality.For further information contact the Brian Steenson Memorial Group secretary, Alan Lyons, telephone   or email alan-lyons@hotmail..prettyPhoto

title: New garden centre and coffee shop set to open
story: AN innovative garden centre and coffee shop is to open in Ballynahinchrsquos High Street on Saturday.Blue Cedar is the brainchild and passion project of  year-old William Getty, from Spa.Five new jobs will be created in the stylish garden centre and gt shop which is sure to appeal to the discerning shopper who appreciates quality and local produce.Known over the last four years as a contract landscaper and gardener with a growing reputation across Northern Ireland, William has long wanted to create his own garden centre.The former Down High School student, who went on to get a BSc in Business Administration from the University of Bath, got into gardening as a child aged  years.Williamrsquos love for transforming open spaces grew from there and his experience widened after he spent a considerable amount of time working on farms both locally and in Australia, which further developed his knowledge and passion.William was also inspired on his travels by the coffee culture in Australia and South America.With the development of Blue Cedar, he has combined both interests in this, his second business, which he intends to run in tandem with Blue Cedar Landscaping.William will be able to directly show clients at Blue Cedar the plants, shrubs and trees he would recommend in any landscaping contract mdash all over a cup of delicious coffee.Since April he has transformed a derelict space in the town into something completely dferent mdash and very much on trend mdash for Ballynahinch.Using three shipping containers, which were winched on to site, he has developed the garden centre, gt shop and coffee shop that will focus on stocking local goods from quality suppliers.While the use of shipping containers may well be unusual for local shoppers and diners, William promises that the interior will provide all the comfort and alitythat coffee fans demand to savour their brew.All labour and materials were sourced from within a  mile radius of Ballynahinch in order to support local businesses.This ethos has been carried into the coffee shop and gt shop were William is supporting local and independent suppliers who provide a range of food, drinks and gts.William has been supported by his family in this new venture, and in particular, he is grateful for the help and support of his girlfriend, Molly, and his sister, Alex, who has moved back from London to help him run the coffee.He would also like to acknowledge friends who have supported him in his latest venture, especially the boys from Ballynahinch Rugby Club who have worked extremely hard to help him get up and running.Blue Cedar at - High Street will be open from am to pm seven days a week..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle bowls pavilion opens
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS impressive new bowling club pavilion has been officially opened.The new facility was opened during a special ceremony last Friday by Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey who was joined by a number of local authority officials, councillors and representatives from several bowling clubs in the area.The creation of the ultra-modern pavilion was identied as an urgent priority in the local councilrsquos sports facility strategy and was fully funded by the organisation with the work carried out by Maghera Developments.Located in the Castle Park area of Newcastle, the new pavilion, which is a welcome boost for home and visiting bowlers, boasts stunning views of the Mournes and will provide perfect hub for bowling in the area.Cllr Casey said the new pavilion also provides an opportunity to raise the profile of bowling in the district.He continued: ldquoThe new pavilion aims to raise the levels of health and well-being of all our citizens both in this district and further afield.ldquoAs a council, we have been determined to improve the health and wellbeing of all our citizens and, to that end, are working to provide modern, attractive and fit-for-purpose facilities.Describing the new bowling club facility as ldquofantastic, the council chairman said it illustrates how the local authorityrsquos sports strategy works for local sport.Cllr Casey added: ldquoThe strategy also reinforces our commitment to delivering quality facilities for our communities. Hopefully, this will encourage new participants to take up bowling and be active..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle four come through Strangford test
story: FOUR Newcastle and District AC athletes mdash and an in-form MAC lady mdash took the picturesque drive through the Lecale countryside to the village of Strangford for their now annual k and k races as part of their yearly festival.Local hotelier Jack OrsquoHare surprised some by taking a half day off work in preparation, but post-race, his only thought was about getting home to ensure family pet rabbit Thistle was locked up safe from any loose dogs in Donard Forest.With the nights now visibly on the turn, fresh from his warm weather training camp in Bundoran, the veteran Connaire McVeigh was also worried about getting home to lock his poultry and take the lonely Woo Woo for a walk.The pre-race talk in the Downpatrick rush hour traffic was which race they would toe the line to.Would they work on stamina in the k or go for speed in the k  Burrenbridgersquos James King, another surprise entry on the night, was aiming to get some race sharpening done beforethe autumn Dublin Marathon and took time out from his gruelling longer miles with coach Higgins.The race started at the quayside with both of the McVeighs, OrsquoHare and King putting their toes to the line together, butpjust as the starters prepared to blow their whistle at .pm the junior Brian McVeigh stepped to the side complaining he had travel sickness and deciding to opt the km which started at .pm.As the k race took off through the village, East Down ACrsquos Aaron McGrady led the pack and went on for a gun to tape victory.With the veteran McVeigh and King running together, leading the chasing field with a picturesque route through the Castleward estate tracks and trails along the lough shores.Eventually, the veteran McVeigh finished in third place overall in a time of . putting it down his recent break from hilly Donard Forest tracks. James crossed the line in fourth in . improving his time from last year.The experienced OrsquoHare crossed the line in eighth place in a time of . having a tremendous battle with k specialist Karen Wilton.With the finish taking you through the village, OrsquoHare was seen checking out local licensed premises for any threats to his warmest beer garden in Ireland.The younger McVeigh took second place in the km race with a time of .. One wonders will he eventually enter a longer race in the distant future as he now considers himself as a short race specialist After post-race refreshments the younger McVeigh and the hotelier OrsquoHare were spotted eating chips and sampling Guinness shandies on the village green.The Newcastle crew then made it for home some to prepare for their long Sunday training runs..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle ready for food and drink festival
story: NEWCASTLE is getting ready for a major food and drink festival next month.The event takes place on Saturday, September , at the Slieve Donard Resort and Spa in conjunction with Taste the Island, a brand-new initiative to promote food and drink on the island of Ireland.The local authority mdash along with Tourism NI, Faacuteilte Ireland and Tourism Ireland mdash will be promoting Taste the Island throughout September, October and November.Exhibitors at this yearrsquos festival include Whitewater Brewery, Jawbox Gin, Kilmegan Cider, Shortcross Gin and Echlinville Gin, along with local food producers including Castlescreen Farm, Kelugos Mini-donuts, Bear Necessities and The Fancy Fox.Council chairman, Charlie Casey, said the Taste the Island event will celebrate the quality, creativity and entrepreneurship from our local producers.He continued: ldquoWe have been working closely with our industry partners to bring our food story to the whole island of Ireland and offer a compelling programme of authentic food and drink experiences to encourage visitors to come to our region.ldquoWe are delighted to support this fabulous food and drink festival and I would urge everyone to come along and taste the best our region has to offer.Slieve Donard Resort and Spa general manager, Michael Weston said now in its third year, the food and drink festival has been established as a popular autumn event in Newcastle.ldquoThis year, we are delighted to introduce some fun for all the family as well as providing the opportunity to showcase some of the fantastic array of local food and drink producers and their offering, he added.The forthcoming festival will have fun for the whole family with pony rides, face painting and balloon modelling and the popular street food stall will make its , with a wide selection of local treats.The festival runs from pm to pm with an entry fee of pound. For further information, call the Slieve Donard Resort on    or visit www.visitmournemountains..prettyPhoto

title: Outstanding GCSE results for students
story: LOCAL students have once again excelled at their GSCE exams mdash with several schools reporting best ever results this year.The achievements of the students, many of whom will go on to sit A-Levels, continued to reflect the district as one of the top performing in Northern Ireland.Overall, girls in Northern Ireland continued to out perform boys but the gap narrowed from . to . percentage points.The Council for the Curriculum, Examinations and Assessmentsaid that there was a slight increase, .%, of students achieving the top A*-C Grades.Unlike the A-level results the previous week, students went to their respective schools last Thursday morning to receive their exam grades.Most students will remain at their schools but some will move into the th form at other schools to sit A-Levels or progress into higher education, apprenticeships or employment.Down High School reported students achieved the best overall GCSE examinations results since the schoolrsquos records began.Overall, .% of Year  pupils attained seven GCSEs at grades A star to Cwith % receiving at least five grades at A star to C.Overall excellence was achieved by  pupils who gained ten straight A star or A grades, with a further  pupils receiving nine A star or A grades. More than half, %, of all the grades achieved were A star or A and over % of all grades were A star to B.Jamie Adams secured ten A* grades, while Andrew Clarke, Molly Crawford and Sarah Magwood all achieved nine A stars and one A.Mrs Maud Perry, principal, was delighted by the successes of the pupils.She said: ldquoDown High pupils are among the best qualied of their generation and beyond the curriculum, our pupils are enriched, socially confident and ready to take their place as leaders of the future in whatever fields they choose.Mr Joe McCann, principal of St. Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, said the outstanding results achieved by the Year  studentsrsquo saw an impressive % of students achieve seven or more GCSE grades at A*-C, including English and Mathematics. Over a third of all grades were A* A and  students were awarded nine or more A* A grades.Mr McCann added: ldquoThese results are testimony to the hard work of the students and the teachers who supported and guided them throughout their two years of GCSE study.St Maryrsquos High School in Downpatrick reported another year of excellent results with % of students achieving five or more GCSE passes at A* -C with % achieving five or more GCSE passes at A* -C, including English and Mathematics.Ms Rosemary McLaughlin, principal, said:The Board of Governors and I I would like to congratulate our Year  students and thank our staff for their dedication and the parents for the very supportive home school partnerships that have culminated in such an excellent set of results.Mr Justin Sharvin, vice-principal of De La Salle High School in Downpatrick, said that the school was delighted with studentsrsquo results.ldquoMany of our pupils achieved the desired grades toto De La Salle for Post  studies as well as take up apprenticeships and other related courses, he added.ldquoThis is testament to the hard work of the pupils coupled with high quality teaching and learning from a dedicated and committed staff.Blackwater Integrated College in Downpatrick said that students achieved the collegersquos best ever results with % gaining five or more GCSEs at grades A star to C mdash which is well above the Northern Ireland average for five or more A-C grades, including Maths and English.Outgoing Head Boy Max McKervey, achieved eight GCSEs while Head Girl Bethany Burke had her efforts rewarded with grades A-C in seven subjects, including Maths and English.Fellow students Niamh Armstrong, Neave Brown, Leo Clarke and Carly Cranston also achieved eight subjects, including Maths and English.The principal, Mr Stephen Taylor, said that the college was looking forward to the new school year and welcoming its biggest ever intake next week.Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch also praised its students for another outstanding year of results with almost a quarter of Year  girls achieving at least nine or more A or A* grades.Over % of all grades were A star to C and virtually all students at the single-sex school, . %, achieved five or more GCSEs.Mr Peter Dobbin, principal, celebrated the diligence and commitment of the students, the dedication of the teachers and the invaluable support of the parents.He said: ldquoWe have a unique school community here at Assumption and I am delighted that the hard work of the whole school community has paid idends. In keeping with our school ethos of lsquoFully Aliversquo, these young women have succeeded in achieving at the highest levels academically while excelling in an array of extra-curricular activities at local, national and international levels, as well as growing in confidence and self-discipline.Mr Mark Morgan, principal of St Colmanrsquos High  Sixth Form College, Ballynahinch, described the schoolrsquos results as ldquoexceptional.He said that % of pupils secured at least five A star to C grades and % secured at least seven A star to C passes.Mr Morgan added: ldquoThese outcomes reflect the hard work of both teachers, pupils and parents and create a strong foundation as students go forward to complete Post  study at the school and then onto higher educational college, university, higher learning apprenticeships or direct employment.The High School in Ballynahinch reported that its GCSE results were ldquowell above the Northern Ireland average.The principal Mr Paul Marks spoke of the schoolrsquos pride at the studentsrsquo achievements.ldquoThis is down to the hard work of the children, the essential support of parents and the dedication of all our staff, all of which I am very grateful, he said.ldquoWe would like to wish our pupils well as they set out on their next steps in education or employment.Mr Seamus Hanna, the newly appointed principal of St Colmcillersquos High School in Crossgar, said he was very proud of the achievements of every single pupil.ldquoAll pupils worked to the best of their abilities and achieved their goals, he added.ldquoThe school has celebrated the success of all their pupils and are confident that all have choices and opportunities for their future.Ms Sarah-Lucy Hynds, principal of Saintfield High School, said that the school and teachers were happy for their Year  students who achieved their ldquopersonal best last week.She added: ldquoA special mention must go to our top performing students mdash Katie Hunter, who achieved six A grades and two B grades, Edith Hogg who was awarded an A star, five As and two B grades, and Erin Sethuraman on achieving an A star, five As and two Bs.ldquoWe wish each and every student much success and happiness for the future and hope that theycontinue to thrive in their chosen pathway.Mr Kevin Lambe, principal of Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle, said that the school was welcoming back ldquorecord numbers into its Sixth Form this week following excellent GCSE results across the curriculum.He said: ldquoWe have students achieving top grades ranging across the traditional academic subjects such as further mathematics, sciences, languages and humanities and the newer vocational subjects such as horticulture, understanding business enterprise with languages and tourism and personal development and employability.ldquoWe also celebrate the students who are moving on to training courses in plumbing, equestrian studies, computing etc in further education.St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan described its studentsrsquo results as ldquooutstanding with % of students achieving A star to C grades in five or more subjects and  students achieving seven or more A star to C grades.The school said many students secured several A star and A grades in a wide range of subjects.The principal Mrs Orla OrsquoNeill praised the students, teachers and parents.ldquoThese wonderful results are very well deserved, reflecting everyonersquos hard work and commitment not only after five years in St Malachyrsquos but also bearing in mind the excellent foundations laid in our feeder primary schools, she said.ldquoValuing every pupil and having high expectations of each one is at the core of what we are about at St Malachyrsquos and this group of students have certainly lived up to these high expectations..prettyPhoto

title: Rebecca to represent Down in Miss Ireland competition
story: A BALLYNAHINCH teacher says she is excited at being selected to represent Co Down in the Miss Ireland beauty pageant.Twenty five year-old Rebecca Leahy will be wearing the Co Down sash when she takes to the catwalk at Dublinrsquos Crowne Plaza Hotel in just over a fortnightrsquos time.Rebecca, a P teacher at Ballynahinch Primary School, was voted No  in Down after coming through a selection process recently.One of the attributes that caught the judgesrsquo eye was her enthusiasm for her fund-raising efforts for childrenrsquos charities.Rebecca has enlisted the support of ious local groups and iniduals in her fund-raising ventures, including the members of Teconnaught GAC.Rebecca, a former pupil at Down High School, said: ldquoI entered the competition during the summer and the winner was officially announced recently.This year was the first time the selection process was conducted through a series of telephone interviews.There will be  other regional finalists going forward to the Miss Ireland final which will be held on Saturday, September .She said: ldquoThe competition is dferent to other beauty pageants in that it promotes lsquobeauty with a purposersquo which is at the heart of the Miss World organisation.ldquoGirls who enter usually are campaigners and fundraisers for local childrenrsquos charities. I have worked closely with Downrsquos and Proud, a local charity set up to inspire families touched by Downrsquos Syndrome and help raise money.ldquoPart of the selection process at the next level is determined by our work with an Irish childrenrsquos charity called Variety Ireland, the charity associated with the competition.ldquoIt is a charity who looks after disadvantaged, sick and under privileged children and is run entirely by a team of professional volunteers who donate their time and services for free.ldquoThis ensures that all funds raised through donations and fundraising initiatives go directly to help children across the island of Ireland who rely on the charityrsquos help.Rebecca, who graduated from Stranmillis College three years ago, considers herself fortunate watching children progress in their learning.ldquoIrsquom very passionate about my job and love working with children. I take great satisfaction from seeing their young minds grow. I love getting up in the mornings and canrsquot wait for my day to start.Rebecca is humbled by the fact she is in the running be the next Miss World, which now in its th year, and is looking forward to the Miss Ireland final.ldquoIt is really lovely to be given the opportunity to meet all the girls taking part who are very friendly and welcoming, she said. There is a great feeling of camaraderie among the girls and we support each other. It is exciting to be able to get to know them better now.Miss World is the worldrsquos most famous beauty pageant. It broadcast to over  countries around the globe and carries a top prize of ,..prettyPhoto

title: Social housing tops council action plan
story: IDENTIFYING sites for social homes across the district is one of the key planks of a new housing action plan which has been officially launched.The plan mdash launched by Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash aims to tackle the districtrsquos social housing crisis head-on as the number of people in urgent need of a roof over their head continues to increase.The launch of the plan follows a major housing conference the local authority organised several months ago which brought together key decision makers to plot a course that can address an issue which local politicians have warned will only increase.Other key agencies including the Housing Executive, Housing Associations, Department for Communities and planners are all involved in the drive to provide more new homes across the district where almost , people are seeking social homes, with almost , of applicants placed in the urgent need category.Moving forward, a new housing sub-group has been set up which includes representatives from ious organisations and others from the community and voluntary sector to focus on agreed priorities and deliver a series of actions identied in the plan.It is intended that the sub-group will report to the lsquoLiving Well Togetherrsquo Community Planning Partnership Board on its progress.In addition to identying suitable land for new housing, the plan also aims to improve access to social and affordable housing and implementing the homelessness action plan.In addition, the local authorityrsquos local development plan will also provide a -year framework to shape the provision of future housing development and support the wider social and economic needs of the district.Council chairman, Charlie Casey, said he was delighted to launch the new action plan and is pleased that, through working in partnership, a number of key priority actions that will address housing need in the district have been agreed.He added: ldquoWe all are aware that there is a great need for social and affordable housing it is increasing and affects all aspect of peoplersquos lives.ldquoThe lack of suitable, quality housing, is not only detrimental to the economy, it also has a real effect on peoplersquos health and wellbeing, something that the council takes very seriously. I hope that by implementing this action plan we can make a real dference to the residents of our district.Last year, there was across-the-board political support for a motion calling for a major housing conference to take place to address the social housing crisis.At the time, it was revealed that Newcastle was a social housing need hot spot with  people on the waiting list for new homes classed in the urgent need category.Politicians were told that a lack of available land to build new homes was exacerbating the crisis in a resort where rented properties were at a premium, with houses that do come on the market snapped up by people for use as holiday homes.Councillors say they are keen for all ious stakeholders collaborating to provide short, medium and long term solutions to tackle the crisis.In addition, they are keen to see a focus on building appropriate housing for the changing needs of the district, including the increasing demand for single occupancy dwellings and housing that meets the needs of vulnerable people.Politicians say more affordable housing is also required as house price growth is higher in Newry, Mourne and Down than the average growth experienced across Northern Ireland.They say there is a need to plan for long term needs, tackle homelessness and the poverty gap, social housing development and accessible homes provision.Politicians say they hope that by working with partners across the statutory, community, voluntary and private sectors, they can come up with solutions..prettyPhoto

title: Special film of Canon’s Excursion brings back memories
story: THE screening of a special short film on the old Canonrsquos Excursion in Downpatrick took place at the townrsquos Ballymote Centre last weekend.Every summer, over  buses packed with local families would head off from the town for a day in Newcastle which to some excited children at the time seemed like a million miles away when in reality it was literally only up the road.New shoes and clothes were purchased ahead of the annual excursion so everyone was looking their best, with families gathering at the St Dillonrsquos Avenue sports pitches before marching to the townrsquos bus station via Edward Street, John Street, Irish Street and Market Street.A fun-filled day was spent in Newcastle, when the summers always felt warmer than they are today, with families ing home by bus, exhausted after a frantic but thoroughly enjoyable day.The last excursion is believed to have been held in the s, but local people last weekend had a unique opportunity to relive those halcyon days, thanks to a new initiative being spearheaded by the Stream Street Residentsrsquo Association.It helped put together the short film which captures some of the the sights and sounds of the Canonrsquos Excursion which was one of the key events in Downpatrickrsquos social calendar.The film was screened last Friday night in front of a number of Stream Street residents and Housing Executive representatives when all those involved in the project were publicly thanked for their support.John Gordon, a member of the Stream Street Residentsrsquo Association, which played a key role in getting the film project off the ground, was delighted to many people attended last weekendrsquos screening.ldquoIt was great to see some of the original Stream Street residents attend the screening which also provided people with an opportunity to reminisce about the old days, particularly the Canonrsquos Excursion which was a big event, he explained.John said the project to produce a film depicting the annual event was launched around two years ago and is pleased those who attended Friday nightrsquos event enjoyed themselves.ldquoA number of old photographs were also on display which brought back many memories for some, he continued. ldquoWe are deeply indebted to everyone involved and those who help make Friday night such a success..prettyPhoto

title: Teenage vandals unleash mayhem
story: ANOTHER weekend of trouble in Downpatrick has sparked calls for action to be taken against teenagers terrorising the community in the Model Farm and Flying Horse areas.A number of cars were again pelted with stones as they drove along the Killough Road, while several fires were also started on Saturday evening.On Sunday, part of the Brannish Road was reported to be barricaded with branches and supermarket trolleys with young people targeting passing cars with stones.The most disturbing incident occurred on Monday evening when a woman driving alone was left frightened after her car was stoned on the Brannish Road as she made her way to work.Police have confirmed that they are aware of the recent trouble and warned those responsible for the unruly behaviour that their involvement could lead to a criminal record and harm their future university and employment prospects.Officers have also appealed to anyone who can assist them with their enquiries to contact them as they work to apprehend those responsible for the trouble.The Flying Horse Ward Community Forum mdash which earlier this year organised a public protest to call for an end to trouble at this part of the town mdash has condemned the weekend incidents.The grouprsquos chairwoman, Lisa Perry, said the continuing trouble was ldquosimply not acceptable and must end. She also appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.Ms Perry said children need to be taught to respect the community where they live, the people of the Model Farm and Flying Horse areas and those who commute along the Killough Road.ldquoResidents and those who use the Killough Road should not have to put up with such behaviour and anyone who knows who is responsible should contact the police, she said.Ms Perry said the message must go out that stoning cars is not acceptable and that those responsible will not be be allowed to get away with what they are doing.ldquoIt does not bear thinking about what would happena driver whose car is stoned loses control of the vehicle and crashes into pedestrians or someonersquos home. Those who throw missiles at cars need to realise the potential consequences of what they are doing. For drivers, this is a terribly frightening experience.Angry residents have also taken to social media to voice their concern about the trouble which has been prevalent at this part of Downpatrick for many years.Parents have also been urged to warn their children not to get involved in behaviour which could lead to serious consequences, with residents branding those responsible for the trouble as ldquodisgraceful. They said their parents should be doing more to stop the unruly behaviour, expressing concern that the trouble has been allowed to continue for too long and must be stopped.ldquoThe trouble is too frequent, said one woman, while a man revealed his van was stoned on two occasions at the Killough Road last month. Worryingly, he reported that children as young as  were responsible.Another resident expressed concern that a driver could lose control of their car after being stoned which could result in a crash and someone being seriously injured.South Down MLA Colin McGrath said local police must respond swtly to the anti-social behaviour, especially after Monday nightrsquos incident when a woman was attacked.ldquoThere has been an escalation of the anti-social behaviour in the Flying Horse and Model Farm area from a number of youths. Cars have been stoned, fires started and people assaulted. This behaviour is unacceptable, he declared.ldquoThe perceived inactivity of the authorities cannot be allowed to send a message that such behaviour is acceptable. The perpetrators must be dealt with.Mr McGrath said police and other statutory agencies require information to challenge the anti-social behaviour and apprehend those responsible.He added: ldquoInformation can be provided confidentially and is needed to help break this cycle of behaviour at this part of Downpatrick.Police have asked anyone who believes they can assist them with their enquiries to make contact using the non-emergency  number or the confidential Crimestoppers number,  ..prettyPhoto

story: Police at the scene of an ongoing security operation in Newtownbutler have confirmed that some form of explosive device has detonated in the area.Deputy Chief Constable Stephen Martin said: ldquoAt around .am this morning Police officers at the scene have reported an explosion in the area of the Cavan Road at its junction with the Wattlebridge Road. There are no reports of any injuries and officers are investigating the cause of the explosion.ldquoPolice had received a report that a suspect device had been left in the area of Wattle Bridge on Saturday evening. The area was secured by police and a full clearance operation began on Sunday morning.ldquoThe initial report received by police indicated that a device had been left on the Wattlebridge Road however the explosion occurred on the main A Cavan Road.ldquoWhile this investigation is at a very early stage I am of the firm belief this was a deliberate attempt to lure police and ATO colleagues into the area to murder them. Although this device was intended to kill police and army personnel the fact that it was placed on a main road the result could well have been devastating for anyone in the immediate vicinity.ldquoThis attack was indiscriminate and reckless and, whilst there is no doubt in my mind that police responding to this call were the target, the reality is that anyone could have been caught up in the explosion. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. The portraits were removed and the offended party, a Mr Lee Hegarty, was consulted on what should replace them.”Lord Maginnis said that the settlement “was signed off by the then secretary of state, Theresa Villiers MP, on the recommendation, I am informed, of her permanent secretary Jonathan Stephens”.Sir Jonathan remains as the NIO’s permanent secretary, its most senior official.A month ago the News Letter revealed that all images of the Queen – even one of her shaking hands with Martin McGuinness – were then banned from the walls of Stormont House. NIO minister Lord Duncan said at the time that the department “takes steps to ensure no such images are displayed in Stormont House”.Reacting to widespread criticism of the move, new Secretary of State Julian Smith then tweeted a small image of the Queen on the mantel piece of his private office within the building, but the NIO declined to say whether it had only been placed there in response to criticism of the initial decision.Mr Smith ordered a civil service review of the initial decisions. Despite having begun at the height of the holiday season, that review has now been completed in an unusually brisk time frame for the slow-turning wheels of bureaucracy.The News Letter understands that a photo of the Queen on her own has been placed in the main entrance corridor of Stormont House - the first place where guests go when visiting the property - along with another image of the Queen with Irish President Michael D Higgins and an image of Prince Charles in a church with the Anglican and Roman Catholic Archbishops of Armagh.The images are part of a wider series of photos, one of which is of commemorations at the Ulster Tower for the fallen at the Somme. story: Tarmac Aberthawrsquos environmental co-ordinator, Kara Bennett, author Alison ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtPowell and Tarmac Abltspan classtruncate-full-screengterthaw communications consultant, Nicola Jenkinslt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Hold on to dreams is message of Penarth author#s new bookRhws Primary pupils at the launch of Tarmac Aberthawrsquos book ndash Whatrltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtsquos a girl to do ltspan classtruncate-full-screengt Includes Evan whorsquos quoted lt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentAN all-woman collaboration has led to the launch of an inspirational childrenrsquos book.Whatrsquos a girl to do  was the dream of Tarmac Aberthawrsquos environmental co-ordinator, Kara Bennett, and communications consultant, Nicola Jenkins ndash but it was after partnering with local author Alison Powell and illustrator, Emily Jones, that the book was brought to le through the eyes of Ellie, a determined young girl who knows what she wants in le but faces negativity and obstacles along the way.Vale AM Jane Hutt and pupils from Rhws Primary were first to hear the story at the launch in Rhoose Community Library on June .Kara explains how the idea was formed: ldquoHaving worked in heavy industry for years Irsquom disheartened to see just how few women consider it a career choice. This, coupled with the feedback from the schoolchildren we work with through our community outreach programme, was enough for us to want to do something about it.ldquoWhatrsquos a girl to do follows Ellie as she sets out on her quest to be an engineer ndash but the road isnrsquot easy. Her classmates think shersquos odd, her best friend, Flo, doesnrsquot understand, her brother says she canrsquot, and her grandad is behaving strangely. Ellie doesnrsquot want to give up on her dream and the book seesshe can make it in a world that can be so negative.Penarth author Alison Powell has been involved from the projectrsquos beginning and helped bring Ellie and her family and friends to le.Ms Powell said: ldquoWhen I was approached I was delighted ndash as a mother of two children, I know how important it is to re-enforce positivity through all aspects of le, to challenge stereotypes and ensure they know they can strive for any career they choose, regardless of gender, race or orientation.Evan, a year two Rhws Primary pupil, said: ldquoI loved the bit in the story where Ellie got a job. People didnrsquot think she could be an engineer, but she proved them wrong. We can do what we want when we work hard.Whatrsquos a girl to do  will be distributed to schools across the area and copies from the initial print run, funded by Tarmac Cement and Lime, can be requested by emailing kara.bennett@tarmac article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: summer festival returns penarth weekend
story: The Summer Festival will run on Saturday and Sunday this weekend" Summer festival s to Penarth this weekendCreator of the Penarth Downhill Derby, Elliot Penn" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentPENARTHS Summer Festival s on Saturday  and Sunday  July.Based on Penarthrsquos seaside Esplanade, Saturday features the thrills of the Downhill Derby soapbox race, with plenty of entertainment, street-food, games and live music before the days events are brought to a close with fireworks from the pier.Sunday is Penarthrsquos traditional carnival day, with a host of free activities to engage all the family, in front of a water ski championship offshore.Last yearrsquos event attracted , over two days and this year in promised to be better than ever.The line-up is as follows:Saturday, July am to pm Alexandra Park Family Bear Huntpm to pm Teddy Bears Picnic in Alexandra Parkpm Esplanade site opens - with stage entertainment until pmpm to pm Downhill Derby.pm DJ Hoarez.pm Funk Soul Band.pm DJ Hoarezpm Funk Soul Band.pm DJ Hoarez and Mor o Goffi.pm FireworksSunday, July am to pm Alexandra Park Family Bear Huntpm to pm Teddy Bears Picnic in Alexandra Parkpm Esplanade site opens, with stage entertainment until pm.pm Sway Dance Performancepm Water Ski Championship.pm St Louis Express live on Stagepm CloseFrom July  to July , the popular Open Air Art Exhibition s to The Clf Walk. Its a chance for visitors to view and purchase unique inidual pieces of art.Artists will be present from noon to pm every day, weather permitting.In line with the townrsquos plastic free status, the festival will be plastic free!As with recent festivals and Picnic Penarths, traders will be using veg ware containers and non-plastic cutlery.This year, drinking containers will be fully biodegradable and no plastic water bottles will be sold.Festival goers are encouraged to use their own cups and bottles, with free drinking water provided from refillable stations.The downhill derby will once again see gravity-powered soapboxes raced against the clock down Clf Hill in a bid to be crowned lsquoKing Queen of the Hillrsquo.Racers travel down a tricky course, with a finish line outside the yacht club.Karts battle against chicanes, water hazards and ramp jumps against the vibrant backdrop of the festival.As well as the race itself, creativity will also be rewarded, with the brightest and craziest karts ndash as well as the fastest ndash earning points as well.Prizes include a Lego cup for the under-s, the title of ldquoMost Spectacular Kart up for grabs, and the ultimate achievement, the  King of the Hill.Co-founder of the Downhill Derby Elliot Penn said: ldquoThis competition is a real labour of love for our volunteers.ldquoWersquore very proud of how Penarth has embraced the event.ldquoEvery year gets bigger and better and  is sure to bring thrills and surprises.ldquoWe welcome all entrants, whether theyrsquore regular racers or new to the Derby.Last year, more than , people flocked to Penarth over the weekend to enjoy the summer festival and downhill derby.With carousels, inflatables, the classic hook-a-duck game and a host of other festival activities, there was plenty of entertainment.Last year there were crashes and some carts didnrsquot make it down the hill, but with helping hands from race officials, every cart crossed the finish line and received support and cheers from the crowds.A couple of notable designs as picked out then by the volunteer race officials included Not So Noo Noo - a big blue fluffy vacuum cleaner loosely modelled on the Teletubbies vacuum cleaner. Last yearrsquos winners were Rapido Burrito, whose team were all in Mexican fancy dress.More information about the event can be found on social media and penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
